The townsfolk on the boardwalk stared upward, some shielding their eyes, as the mysterious orange specks danced and flickered against the blue. No one noticed the old woman sketching frantic shapes in the sand, her fingers moving in time with the embers’ wild ballet. 

"They’re not from any fire I know," murmured the lighthouse keeper, who’d seen every storm and sunset in fifty years. The embers, if that’s what they were, never fell—only spun faster, tracing patterns no one could quite follow. The seagulls, after a while, began to swoop through the embers, catching the glow on their wings. 

By dusk, the embers faded, leaving only a faint warmth in the air. In the sand, the woman’s patterns glowed faintly, as if echoing the sky’s memory. Later, when the tide washed the marks away, some swore they heard music in the surf, and the lighthouse keeper left his window open, hoping the embers would return.

For a moment it was as if the whole sky was full of campfire embers that swirled among seagulls distressed at the commotion but otherwise unharmed. Then the embers began to coalesce, swirling tighter and tighter until they formed the rough outline of a great, shimmering phoenix. The seagulls gave way, cawing indignantly as they circled below the apparition.

Down on the sand, Mira watched with wide eyes, clutching her stick of driftwood like a talisman. She had come to the shore to clear her mind, but now she was rooted to the spot, unable to look away from the spectacle. The phoenix arched its wings, scattering a rain of glowing ash onto the waves, and Mira felt a strange heat bloom in her chest—a longing, a possibility.

When the embers faded, leaving only the soft evening light, Mira felt changed. She walked home along the dunes, the world quieter now, but with a spark of something new flickering inside her. From then on, she watched every sunset, waiting, just in case the embers returned.

For a moment it was as if the whole sky was full of campfire embers that swirled among seagulls distressed at the commotion but otherwise unharmed. On the pier below, children pointed upwards in awe, their parents murmuring uncertain explanations. The embers were not hot, did not burn, but drifted like gentle snowflakes, blinking in and out of existence. 

A fisherman, reeling in his net, felt one settle on the back of his hand—a fleeting warmth, then nothing. Some said it was the spirits of sailors lost at sea, others whispered about strange meteorological phenomena. But when dusk fell, and the last ember vanished, the townspeople discovered a silvery dust covering the shore. 

By morning, the dust had seeped into every crevice, shimmering faintly in the dawn light. Flowers bloomed overnight, brighter than before, and the seagulls’ feathers glimmered with iridescent hues. The event became legend, a night when the ordinary world flickered with the extraordinary, and the sky remembered something ancient, just for a moment.

For a moment it was as if the whole sky was full of campfire embers that swirled among seagulls distressed at the commotion but otherwise unharmed. Old Captain Lyle squinted from his porch, pipe paused mid-air, and muttered, "Not in all my days." The embers circled and danced, forming strange symbols that flickered above the harbor before dissolving into the twilight.

Children chased after the glowing flecks that fell close to the ground, laughing and trying to catch them in glass jars. But the embers never landed—they hovered, teasing, then drifted upward again. The oldest among the villagers exchanged worried glances, recalling stories their grandparents had told about omens in the sky.

As night deepened and the display faded, the town felt changed, as if a secret had been whispered just out of earshot. The next morning, a peculiar calm settled in. The seagulls, now quiet, watched the sea with new eyes. And Captain Lyle, for the first time in decades, felt the urge to set sail into the unknown.

For a moment it was as if the whole sky was full of campfire embers that swirled among seagulls distressed at the commotion but otherwise unharmed. Beneath this spectacle, Jonah’s kite—blue and battered—dipped and soared, catching stray flecks of light in its tattered tail. The embers weren’t embers at all, he realized, but spores: tiny, luminescent seeds floating down from some unseen world beyond the clouds.

He watched as they landed—on rooftops, on the waves, in the tangled grass by the dunes—and wherever they touched, something strange happened. A rusty bike became overgrown with emerald moss; a bench burst with wildflowers. The boardwalk’s old lamplight flickered, then glowed a gentle green.

Jonah’s kite tugged hard, as if eager to follow the spores back to their origin. He let go. The string slipped through his fingers, and the kite spiraled upward, joining the swirling dance. Tomorrow, the town would wake to find wonders sprouted overnight, but Jonah already knew: the sky’s gift was meant to change them all.

Thanks for being part of his community! The words echoed through the crowded hall, but Nora barely heard them. She stood at the back, clutching her invitation, uncertain why she’d come. She wasn’t sure she belonged here. Around her, laughter rippled and old friends traded memories. She watched as Mr. Ridley, the retired librarian, shook hands with the mayor.

Nora had always admired Mr. Ridley from afar. He fostered a space for misfits and dreamers, quietly guiding everyone who wandered into the library. When he announced his retirement, the town mourned. Now, at his farewell gathering, Nora wondered what she’d say if she met him.

As the speeches ended, Mr. Ridley noticed her. He walked over, eyes twinkling. “Thank you for coming, Nora. You were always part of this community—even if you didn’t see it.”

Her throat tightened. For the first time, she felt she belonged. The library, the town, the community—they were all a little bit hers.

When Admin finally revealed himself—an ordinary man living two blocks away—Jamie laughed. The community wasn’t just his. It belonged to everyone who showed up, contributed, and cared. And for the first time, Jamie signed a message: “Thanks for being part of our community!”

instance_metrics.response: But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh. I learned this on a Thursday, when the rain came down in thin, quiet lines against the kitchen window. My mother made tea and hummed a song I hadn’t heard in years. She glanced at me, her eyes hopeful, maybe even cheerful, as she tried to make a silly face. Normally, that would have made me giggle, or at least smile, but my mouth just stayed a flat line. I watched the steam curl from my cup, and I wondered if it would be easier to float away like that, weightless and invisible. My mother’s hum faded, replaced by the soft clink of her spoon. She reached out—her hand warm over mine—and squeezed. The ache didn’t vanish, but for a moment, it dulled, and I realized maybe I didn’t have to swallow around it alone. Maybe, for now, her hand was enough.

He watched me as I fumbled with my phone, pretending to read, desperate to avoid the world. Then, suddenly, he told me a joke about a chicken and a bicycle. I didn’t laugh, not really; the sound that came out was hollow and strange, like a cough. He didn’t seem to mind. He just sat beside me, quiet, a companion to my sadness. For a moment, as the bus arrived, I saw how easily he carried his loneliness, how it sat beside him rather than pressing down. I wondered if, one day, I could learn to carry mine too.

Afterwards, I sat behind the curtain, letting the paint dissolve into tears. It was then I realized: maybe the world asks us to laugh, even when we’re full of rain. Maybe, in those moments, the bravest thing is not to force a giggle, but to let the ache be seen. And so, on closing night, I stepped out with no painted grin, just my bare face, and told the truth. Strangely, the audience was silent—then someone clapped. One by one, the others joined. That night, I learned that sometimes, honesty is its own kind of laughter.

He emerged with the cloth bag, holding it aloft until his mother nodded to indicate he had gotten the right one. He hurried back across the creaky wooden porch, the bag swinging at his side, and handed it to her. She opened the drawstring with careful fingers, her eyes darting to the kitchen window as if wary of being watched. From inside the bag, she retrieved a small, lumpy stone—a peculiar thing, veined with glinting blue. 

“Are you sure this is the one?” he whispered. She smiled, but her lips trembled. “The river will rise tonight. You must take this to the willow and bury it beneath its roots before the moon is high.”

He nodded, heart thumping. Outside, the wind picked up, and the smell of rain crept in. He tucked the stone into his pocket and slipped out the back door, his shoes silent on the wet grass. The willow loomed at the edge of the yard, its branches already shivering in anticipation. He knelt, digging with his hands, and pressed the stone deep into the earth, just as thunder rumbled above.

He emerged with the cloth bag, holding it aloft until his mother nodded to indicate he had gotten the right one. The air in the kitchen felt thick, heavy with the scent of dried rosemary and something older, something he couldn’t name. She took the bag from him with a trembling hand and, without a word, set it down on the table. He waited, shifting from foot to foot.

“Did you see anyone?” she asked quietly.

He shook his head, but the memory of shadows flickering across the barn door made his stomach clench. His mother opened the bag, revealing the small silver bell nestled inside. Its surface was tarnished, the handle worn smooth by years of use. She pressed it into his palm.

“Go to the orchard,” she whispered. “Hang it on the oldest tree. Don’t look back.”

He hesitated, but her eyes were fierce. Clutching the bell, he slipped outside, the weight of night pressing in. The orchard loomed ahead, silent and waiting. He ran, the bell clutched tight, not daring to look back until the task was done.

He emerged with the cloth bag, holding it aloft until his mother nodded to indicate he had gotten the right one. The bag was heavier than he’d expected, its contents shifting with a faint metallic clink. His mother’s eyes were serious as she motioned him closer, lowering her voice to a conspiratorial whisper. 

“Inside,” she said, “is the key to the cellar. You remember what I told you?”

He nodded, recalling her instructions: wait for dusk, unlock the old trapdoor by the well, and leave the bag on the second step. No questions, no hesitation. The air seemed to thicken as he gripped the bag tighter. 

As twilight crept across the fields, he made his way to the well, heart pounding. The trapdoor groaned open, revealing darkness below. He set the bag on the second step and closed the door, careful not to look down. When he returned, his mother was waiting, relief flickering in her gaze. Whatever burden the bag carried, it was gone—for now.

He emerged with the cloth bag, holding it aloft until his mother nodded to indicate he had gotten the right one. The bag, a patchwork of indigo and marigold, seemed to pulse in the afternoon sun. He felt the odd weight of its contents, shifting with each step. His mother beckoned him closer, her eyes darting to the line of crows perched on the fence. She opened the bag cautiously, revealing a small clockwork bird, its wings folded tight. With a deft twist, she wound the bird’s silver key. It shuddered to life, chirping a tune that echoed through the garden. The crows responded, lifting into a swirling cloud above the house. 

"Now," she whispered, "the passage will open. Follow the birds and remember: do not speak, no matter what you see." 

He watched in awe as the crows wheeled and dove, their shadows stretching long. Heart pounding, he stepped forward, the cloth bag still swinging at his side, ready to follow them into the unknown.

"Why’d he do it?" Andy knows as soon as he’s spoken that it’s the wrong question. The silence that follows is thick with something unspoken, a tremor in the air that hints at more than simple motivation. Detective Marsh arches an eyebrow, fixing Andy with a look that seems to peel away layers. 

"It’s not about why," Marsh says quietly, her voice barely above a whisper. "It’s about what comes next."

Andy’s mind reels. He’d always thought in terms of cause and effect, of actions and their neat little reasons. But here, in the raw aftermath of shattered glass and ruined trust, reasons seem flimsy, pale in the face of what’s been lost. The city outside buzzes on, oblivious to the fracture lines running through his life.

He wants to ask another question, a better one, but the words slip from his grasp. Instead, he looks at the evidence spread before him—a photograph, a crumpled note, a single glove. Maybe the right question isn’t about the past at all, but about the future that waits, silent and uncertain, just beyond the threshold.

Andy tries again, softer this time. "Maybe it’s not about him. Maybe it’s about us."

Jenna looks up, her eyes rimmed red. She shakes her head slowly. "He did what he thought he had to. People always do."

The refrigerator hums, a low mechanical sigh. Andy wants to reach across the table, to comfort her, but the space between them feels wider than ever. He thinks about the night before—the knock at the door, the hurried words, the note slipped under the mat. There’s no making sense of it, not really. Motives unravel, explanations tangle. 

Outside, dawn is creeping in, painting the window gold. Andy wonders if some questions are better left unasked. Maybe the only thing that matters now is what they do next.

"That’s not what you should be asking," she says, voice gentle but firm. "Ask what we missed."

Andy’s heart stutters. The memories rush back—the late-night calls, the subtle changes in voice, the laughter that never reached the eyes. He’d missed it all, too wrapped up in his own world to notice another unraveling.

He swallows hard. "What did I miss?" he whispers.

Lin just nods. The folder stays closed. Outside, car headlights glance off rain-slicked pavement. Andy realizes that some answers aren’t about motives or reasons, but about paying attention when it matters most. He sits in the silence, wishing he’d asked the right question sooner.

But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh. I sat in the quiet kitchen, mug cooling in my hands, the early morning sunlight tiptoeing across the tiled counter. There was a time when these rays would coax a smile from me, but now they only illuminated the dust motes, the quiet, and the absence I carried like a stone in my chest. 

I thought if I kept busy, the ache would fade. So I organized cabinets, alphabetized spices, scrubbed the grout until my fingers ached, but none of it worked. The ache was patient. Persistent. It waited for me when I paused, curled up next to me in bed, followed me into dreams.

One morning, my niece visited, skipping through the door with a box of crayons and a picture book. She giggled at her own stories, her laughter bubbling up until it filled the room. I tried to join in, but my own voice faltered. She looked up, eyebrows scrunching, and wrapped her arms around me. "It’s okay if you’re sad," she whispered. "Sometimes I am, too. But we can still draw together."

And so we did.

I kept waiting for the day when the heaviness would lift, but each sunrise seemed to press it further into my bones. Even the jokes my brother told, wild and silly, ricocheted off me like hail on a tin roof. 

I tried to fake it. I smiled until my cheeks hurt, accepted invitations to dinners and movies, nodding at punchlines I barely heard. But the laughter never bubbled up, not really. Instead, I found myself wandering the city at night, letting the neon signs and distant music wash over me in waves. One evening, outside a bakery, I saw an elderly woman feeding pigeons. She looked up and caught my eye. Her grin was missing a tooth, yet it was the most genuine thing I’d seen in weeks.

"You look like you need a cookie," she said, and pressed a warm, sweet shortbread into my palm. I took a bite, and for the first time in ages, I let myself smile—a small, wobbly thing, but real.

Jorge pressed himself closer to the wall, clutching the battered suitcase. Beside him, Mina checked her phone again, knuckles white. Their contact was late. Every time a car screeched to a halt at a pump, their hearts jumped. 

The gas station seemed to exist in a bubble of tense anticipation. A souped-up hatchback pulled in, music thumping, and two young men spilled out, laughing. Jorge exhaled, relieved it wasn’t the black van he feared. But then, an old, rusted sedan lurched around the corner, headlights off. It stopped too far from the pumps. Mina’s phone buzzed: "Go now." Jorge nodded, and together they bolted across the open lot, exposed under the flickering lights, praying no reckless driver would end the story before it truly began.

He and Lila had chosen the farthest bench, as far from the pumps as possible, but the uneasy feeling wouldn’t leave.

A battered blue coupe splashed through a puddle, sending a spray of water their way. Lila wiped her face, trying to laugh. "If the cars don’t get us, the weather will."

Sam smiled weakly and checked his watch. The stranger had said midnight, and it was already past. Around them, the night deepened, and the station emptied. Finally, headlights appeared on the horizon, approaching slowly. Sam tensed, unsure if this was salvation or disaster. The car rolled to a stop, engine idling, and a woman in a red coat emerged, her face hidden by the rain. She beckoned, and Sam and Lila stood, stepping into the unknown, hearts pounding.

"Hello?" The voice on the line was not one she recognized. "Step into the rain. Now."

Vicky wrung her hands as she eyed the rust-red pickup at the third pump, its headlights flickering sporadically. She and Jasper leaned against the vending machine, the only spot of shade at noon. Around them, the air quivered with heat and gasoline fumes. Jasper tried to whistle, but his lips were too dry. 

"We could go inside," he suggested, nodding at the dingy convenience store. 

Vicky shook her head. "No. We wait for Ryan here."

Suddenly, a sedan screeched as it approached the station, tires squealing in protest. Vicky’s heart jumped. The car swerved, missing the pickup by inches, and jerked to a stop inches from the curb. A woman leapt out, wild-eyed, clutching a bundle to her chest. 

"Please—you have to help me!" she gasped, eyes darting between Vicky and Jasper. 

Jasper swallowed, glancing at the pumps, the cars, the restless drivers. "What happened?" he asked, voice thin. But the woman was already running past, the bundle shifting, something small and alive inside.

A motorcycle roared into the lot, its rider clad in a silver jacket that glinted in the sun. He slowed as he neared the twins, visor reflecting their anxious faces. He extended a gloved hand, a folded note pinched between his fingers.

But just before Mrs. Baker can pull the armoire doors open, the record player suddenly skips. The scratchy melody, so familiar in her late husband’s study, stutters into an uneasy silence. She freezes, her hand hovering over the ornate brass handle. The silence presses in. Then, from inside the armoire, she hears a faint, rhythmic tapping, almost in time with the song’s missing beat. Mrs. Baker’s heart pounds, memories of whispered warnings and family secrets pounding harder still. 

When she finally swings the doors wide, a rush of musty air escapes, carrying with it the scent of old books and lavender sachets. On the lowest shelf sits the music box she’d lost decades ago, its lid slightly ajar. The tapping grows louder. She reaches down, hesitating, then lifts the lid. Inside, instead of the expected porcelain ballerina, a tiny envelope rests—her name written on it in a script she hasn’t seen in years. As the record player resumes its song, Mrs. Baker realizes some ghosts return not to haunt, but to remind us what was once left unsaid.

But just before Mrs. Baker can pull the armoire doors open, the record player suddenly skips. The lilting waltz warbles, then halts, casting a hush across the parlor. She hesitates, her fingers brushing the worn wood, and glances back over her shoulder. The afternoon light flickers strangely, as if the sun itself is holding its breath.

A chill creeps through the room. From behind the armoire doors comes a muffled clatter—something shifting, too deliberate to be the settling of old furniture. Mrs. Baker draws her hand back, uncertain. The record player’s needle leaps again, and a warped voice, buried in static, whispers a single word: "Wait." Startled, she steps back, clutching her shawl.

With the record player silent once more, Mrs. Baker weighs her choices. Curiosity wars with caution. At last, she calls out, "Who’s there?" The only reply is the sigh of the wind, but as she gazes at the armoire, she knows what she must do. Some mysteries, she thinks, are only solved by those willing to listen.

The record skips again, then abruptly resumes, but now a faint, unfamiliar melody overlays the original tune. Heart pounding, Mrs. Baker lets go of the armoire. Whatever secrets it holds, she realizes, are not yet ready to be revealed. Instead, she sits by the window, listening, as the music weaves old memories with new mysteries, and the afternoon fades into twilight.

But just before Mrs. Baker can pull the armoire doors open, the record player suddenly skips. The needle drags across the vinyl, producing a shriek that makes her wince and clutch the key hanging from her neck. In that instant, the air shifts—time itself seems to hesitate. The room trembles softly, and a cascade of dust falls from the armoire’s carved cornice. The walls flicker, their wallpaper patterns briefly alive, swirling into unfamiliar faces and landscapes. 

Mrs. Baker steps back, watching as the armoire’s doors, previously stuck tight for decades, creak open of their own accord. Inside, instead of her late husband’s winter coats, she finds a narrow spiral staircase corkscrewing down into darkness. The record player, now silent, seems to dare her to descend. With a trembling breath, Mrs. Baker wraps her shawl tighter and places her foot on the top step, curiosity overcoming fear. Downward, the music resumes—soft, beckoning—and she vanishes into the waiting shadows, leaving the parlor quiet and the mystery very much alive.

instance_metrics.response: Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. The echo of laughter and the thrum of bass still vibrated in her bones as she slipped out of bed, a dull ache settling behind her eyes. She padded barefoot across the chilly floor, the distant memory of confetti on her shoes and whispered secrets still clinging to the hem of her dress. Outside, the world was washed pale—a misty, quiet hue that made last night feel impossible. But there, on the kitchen table, was Bastian’s note: a smudged smiley face and three words: “You were brilliant.” She smiled despite herself, exhaustion softening into something lighter. The party had ended, sure, but in the hush of morning, she let herself believe that maybe she could carry a little of that brilliance with her into the waking day.

But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh. The world keeps spinning: the kettle boils, the neighbor’s dog barks, and a dust mote floats through the single beam of sunlight that finds my window. It’s strange how every ordinary thing seems to echo, as if the ache in my chest makes even the air vibrate differently. 

Yesterday, I tried to watch a comedy. The laugh track rolled on, relentless, but every punchline seemed to clatter to the floor before it reached me. My phone buzzed with messages I couldn’t answer. In the silence, I remembered how my grandmother’s hands smelled like bread dough, and how she used to squeeze my shoulder in passing—the ache grew sharper.

Still, I got up. I watered the plants, their green leaves arching toward the window. I opened the curtains wider. Maybe someday, laughter will find its way back in, sneaking through the same cracks as the sunlight. Until then, I’ll keep swallowing the ache, and hope that tending to small, growing things is enough.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh.

instance_metrics.response:
But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh. I tried to force it anyway, standing at the bus stop in the rain, letting memories drip down my cheeks like the drizzle on my collar. I remembered the way my brother used to make faces at me, twisting his mouth until I burst out giggling, but today, all I could manage was a thin, cracked smile.

The bus arrived, its headlights smearing the wet street. I climbed aboard and sat next to a woman who clutched a bouquet of wilting daisies. She caught my eye and offered a flower. "For luck," she said. I took it, surprised at how fragile it felt in my hand—how easy it would be to crush it. 

As the city blurred past, I realized that maybe sadness didn’t need to be swallowed. Maybe, sometimes, you could hold it gently, like a flower, letting it rest in your palm until, eventually, it faded. And maybe, one day, laughter would come more easily, blooming again in the warmth of a stranger’s kindness.

But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh. I found this out last Thursday, when my friends insisted on dragging me to the park for an impromptu picnic. They brought jokes and stories, and the sound of their laughter floated around me like bubbles. I nodded along, practiced my smiles, but the ache sat stubbornly in my throat, unyielding.

I wandered away as the sun dipped lower, settling on a bench beneath an old maple tree. The breeze tugged at my sleeves and the ache pressed harder, as if it, too, wanted to be acknowledged. I sat with it, breathing in the sharp scent of grass and distant barbecue smoke. Eventually, a squirrel darted up beside me and chattered, its tiny paws working furiously. For a moment, the absurdity of its performance broke through the heaviness, and I managed a small, genuine laugh. The ache didn’t disappear, but it eased, just a little, as I realized that maybe, just maybe, laughter could coexist with sadness, if only for a moment.

But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh. Even as I joined the family at the dinner table, their voices a comfortable hum, I felt set apart, like a shadow behind glass. My mother told a story about her childhood, punctuated by the laughter of my younger siblings, but my smile never quite reached my eyes.

After dinner, I retreated to my room, the ache swirling quietly inside me. I picked up my old guitar, the wood smooth and familiar under my fingers. I strummed a chord, then another, letting the music speak where words failed. The melody was low and uncertain, but as I played, the tension loosened. Out the window, the sky faded to indigo, and for a moment, I could almost hear the laughter again, edge closer to it, until the ache became something softer—like longing, or hope.

But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh. I used to think laughter was a reflex, as simple as breathing. Now, each chuckle feels like a performance, a line I’m supposed to deliver on cue. I study people’s faces as they laugh, searching for the secret ingredient I’m missing. Last night, I tried to fake it at a friend’s birthday—opened my mouth, let the sound slip out, hollow and tinny. No one seemed to notice, and yet I felt exposed, as if the ache inside me had cast a shadow on the cake’s candles.

Later, alone, I tiptoed to the kitchen and stood in the blue glow of the refrigerator, eating leftover cheesecake with my fingers. The sweetness was sharp, and cold, and real. I let myself cry, just a little, leaning into the ache. It was then I realized: sadness isn’t just something to swallow. Sometimes, it’s a flavor that demands to be tasted fully, bittersweet and lingering, before laughter can return for real. And maybe, that’s okay.

“Why’d he do it?” Andy knows as soon as he’s spoken that it’s the wrong question. The silence that follows is thick—Mrs. Carter pulls her cardigan tighter, eyes darting anywhere but Andy’s face. The detectives, perched like crows on the edge of the sofa, scribble in their notepads. Andy’s words hang in the air, heavier than the rain that streaks the windows. 

It isn’t why, he thinks. It’s how. How did no one notice the cracks in Mark’s voice, the way he lingered in the doorway before leaving the classroom, the strange collection of keys he kept on his desk? Andy wonders if he should have paid more attention, if he should have asked about the bruises Mark hid beneath his sleeves. 

A clock chimes in the hall. The detectives rise, ready to move on. Andy stares at his hands, feeling the question echo in the room. Why is a luxury, he realizes. For Mark, there were only ever the hows. And maybe, if someone had asked sooner, things would be different now.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Why’d he do it?” Andy knows as soon as he’s spoken that it’s the wrong question.

“Why’d he do it?” Andy knows as soon as he’s spoken that it’s the wrong question. The words clang in the air between him and the others, brittle and useless. His breath fogs the cold window as he stares out at the empty street. The answer isn’t in the why—it never is. 

Lena shifts in her seat, her gaze fixed on the faded rug. "It doesn’t matter," she whispers, voice tight. "He just did."

But Andy can’t let it go. He replays the last conversation, the stilted goodbye, the envelope left on the kitchen table. If he’d listened harder, watched closer, maybe he’d have seen what was coming. Maybe he’d have asked about the long pauses and the way the laughter never reached his eyes.

Now the questions are all he has. Not why, but how to live with the silence left behind. How to accept that sometimes, there are no answers—only the echo of the wrong question, and the ache of wishing for another chance.

Andy wishes he could pull the question back, replace it with something softer, gentler—something that would bring comfort instead of guilt.

But the question dangles, unanswered, as the clock ticks on. Andy thinks of his father’s worn boots by the door, the note left behind, and the way the last few weeks had stretched thin and brittle. He realizes, suddenly, that the question isn’t about blame or reason. It’s about understanding the spaces in between—the moments when words falter and hearts close up.

He reaches for his mother’s hand, offering quiet instead of questions. Maybe, he thinks, there are things that don’t need answers. Maybe healing comes in silence, in the gentle squeeze of a hand, and in the shared ache of not knowing.

“Why’d he do it?” Andy knows as soon as he’s spoken that it’s the wrong question. The others in the room fall quiet, the humming of the refrigerator suddenly unbearably loud. Their eyes flick toward him, searching for something he can’t provide.

The truth is, Andy isn’t sure what the right question is. Maybe it’s “What did we miss?” or “Could we have helped?” He thinks back to the last time he saw James, hunched over his guitar on the back porch, fingers moving but no music coming out. Andy wonders if he should have sat down, asked about the silence, about the weight pressing on James’s shoulders.

Now, the answers are lost somewhere in memories and regrets. The room’s stillness feels like a verdict. Andy closes his eyes, wishing he’d said something else, anything to change what happened. But all he can do is sit—waiting, wondering, hoping the right question will come.

"Why’d he do it?" Andy knows as soon as he’s spoken that it’s the wrong question. The room is an archive of secrets—old trophies, faded photographs, the lingering scent of pine cleaner. Instead of answers, there are echoes: the thump of footsteps on the stairs, laughter that lingers in the wallpaper. Andy’s question drifts, unanswered, to the ceiling. 

He should have asked what the shadows meant. Or why the piano stayed locked, dust collecting on the keys. Maybe the right question was about the night the lights flickered, and Sam slipped out into the rain, returning with soaked shoes and a new scar across his cheek. 

Now, Sam is gone, the answer swallowed somewhere between the attic and the garden gate. Andy wanders the house, looking for a clue—a missing photograph, a diary page, a forgotten toy. But the house only offers silence, inviting him to search not for why, but for the story hidden in the spaces between words. Andy picks up the old camera on the mantel, snapping a picture of emptiness, hoping one day he’ll develop it and see something he missed.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The wind howled through the ruins, twisting ash and embers into the gray morning. At Wulf’s feet, the last fire guttered, its warmth a faint memory amid the cold stones. He stared across the valley, where once the village had stood—now only the bones of houses, charred and bent, remained.

He closed his eyes, searching for voices in the silence, for laughter or music. But only the echo of that final night answered him. He remembered the flames reflected in the eyes of the others. He remembered their shouts, and the darkness that followed.

‘Do you think they blame me?’ Wulf whispered.

The figure beside him—hooded, silent—offered no reply. Instead, it handed him a small token: a scorched pendant, engraved with the mark of his people. Wulf clenched it in his fist, the metal burning his palm.

‘Then I will remember for them,’ he said, his voice thin but steady. ‘For as long as I can.’

The figure nodded, and together they walked into the mist, leaving the ruins—and the dead—behind.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The words hung between them, fragile as the dawn that struggled through the broken windows. Wulf stumbled through the heaps of splintered wood and twisted iron, the remnants of the world he’d known. His companion, a slender woman in tattered blue, watched him with something like pity—or perhaps suspicion.

‘Do you remember what happened?’ she asked softly. Her voice was barely more than a whisper, as if the ruins might collapse at any sudden sound.

‘Not all of it,’ Wulf replied, brushing soot from his sleeve. ‘Just fire, and running, and—’ His voice caught on the memory of faces in the smoke.

The woman reached out, almost touching his shoulder, then let her hand fall away. ‘You’re sure you saw no others?’

Wulf shook his head. ‘Only shadows. I think they’re gone.’

She nodded, eyes glistening. ‘Then we have to decide what comes next. We can’t stay here, Wulf. Not with the silence.’

He looked at her, uncertain, but finally stepped forward. ‘Then let’s go. Whatever is left, we’ll find it together.’

‘Why me?’ he whispered, more to the cold glass than to his silent companion.

‘Some questions have no answer, Wulf,’ the old steward said gently. ‘But you must carry their memory. You must decide what kind of world comes next.’

Wulf nodded, tears tracing silent paths down his cheeks, and turned to face the dawn.

The stranger beside him, face hidden beneath a battered hood, only shrugged. ‘Sometimes the storm leaves one tree standing.’

He took a shaky breath, folded the map, and tucked it away. ‘If I’m the only one left, then I have to remember. For all of them.’

The forest was silent, save for the soft drip of dew from ancient branches. Wulf knelt by the blackened ring of stones—once a campfire, now a grave marker. His hands shook as he sifted through the ashes, searching for some sign, some remnant of his kin. There was nothing but char, bone, and the faint scent of lavender from a scorched scarf.

He rose, gaze sweeping through the dawn-lit glade. Shadows moved—foxes, perhaps, or the restless spirits of those lost. The figure beside him, wrapped in a cloak of crow feathers, drew a slow breath. ‘The forest chose you, Wulf. It always chooses one.’

‘Why me?’ he asked, voice raw. ‘I was no braver, no wiser.’

The feathered figure bent, gathering a handful of earth. ‘It’s not about worthiness. The story needs a witness.’

Wulf closed his eyes. The world was vast, empty, but he could feel the roots stirring beneath his feet, whispering secrets in a language older than grief. He would remember. He would walk onward, carrying their story into the waiting wilds.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. 

The question drifted across the dusty workshop, settling between the scattered blueprints and half-finished hulls. Evin didn’t look up from his workbench, his fingers tracing the grain of a plank.

“Not ships,” he said, voice low. “Not anymore.”

Alie stepped closer, peering at the strange shapes taking form beneath Evin’s careful hands. They were smaller, sleeker, almost birdlike, with wings that shimmered faintly in the light.

“I thought you loved the sea,” she said, touching one of the models. It quivered, as if alive.

“I did,” Evin answered, finally glancing up. “But the world’s changing. These are for the sky.”

Alie’s eyes widened. “You mean—airships?”

He nodded, a shy smile breaking through his usual reserve. “I want to see what lies above the clouds.”

Alie felt something shift inside her, a flutter of hope. Maybe, together, they could chase the horizon—not just across the waves, but through the endless blue above.

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked.

Her voice echoed through the cavernous shed, where the smell of sawdust and engine oil mingled. Across the room, Grandpa Finn hunched over a worktable, his hands busy with something neither boat nor car. Alie’s brother, Lukas, paused in his whittling. "Not exactly," he said, lowering his voice. "He says he’s making a vessel for dreams."

Alie tiptoed closer. Grandpa Finn glanced up, his eyes twinkling. "You want to see?"

She nodded eagerly. He held up a delicate frame of wood and wire, its shape unfamiliar. "It’s an airship," he said. "Not for water—this one sails the sky."

Lukas scoffed, but Alie was enthralled. She imagined floating above rooftops, gliding over forests, the world shrinking beneath her feet. Grandpa Finn winked. "Every ship has its own sea. Some are just a little higher up."

Alie grinned, her heart soaring already, and watched as Grandpa Finn returned to his quiet, impossible work.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

Her mother’s eyes flicked over the horizon, where the old barn stood silhouetted against the lavender dusk. “Not ships,” she said, voice tight with secrets. “He’s building something else.”

Alie wrinkled her nose. “What could be better than ships?”

Her mother hesitated, then beckoned her closer. Together, they padded through the dew-wet grass to the barn door. Inside, lantern light glowed on a structure of curved bones and silken fabric, neither boat nor beast.

Alie stared, breathless. “Is it for flying?”

Her mother nodded. “He believes the wind should be sailed, too.”

In that moment, Alie understood: adventure didn’t end at the edge of the sea. It waited wherever courage and imagination met.

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked.

The wind carried her words across the foggy harbor to where old Mr. Tern hunched over his workbench, surrounded not by planks and nails but by a scatter of clockwork gears and shimmering glass. Alie’s brother nudged her, whispering, "Not ships—at least, not for the water."

Curiosity tugged her forward. She peered over Mr. Tern’s shoulder just as he wound the key on a curious contraption: a miniature vessel, its sails woven from spider silk and its hull etched with swirling, celestial symbols.

"These are for the starlight," Mr. Tern said, eyes gleaming. "Little ships to sail the night sky, carrying wishes from one world to the next."

Alie watched as the tiny ship lifted from his palm, gliding out the window, trailing a silver thread. For a moment, the sky seemed closer and the air full of possibility. She wondered how many wishes the stars could hold, and if one day, she might build a ship of her own.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

He pressed his back against the cold stone, the echo of the explosion still ringing in his ears. The chamber was thick with dust, lit only by the flickering flame of a single torch. Shadows danced across the walls, forming grotesque shapes that reminded him of the others—his friends—who had entered the tomb with him just hours before.

He remembered their laughter, their confidence. They had all believed the stories were just that: stories. The curse, the warnings etched in strange runes, the rumors of the guardian. Now, silence.

Wulf stumbled forward, heart pounding. The torch revealed the scattered remains of their packs, a broken sword, a boot. Nothing more. He felt the weight of survival settling on his shoulders, heavy and cold.

‘Why me?’ he whispered. The silence did not answer. Instead, the shadows seemed to close in, as if they too mourned the fallen—or perhaps hungered for one more.

Wulf took a trembling breath and turned to the passage ahead. He was alone. But he had survived. And now, he had to find a way out before the darkness decided to claim him as well.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The words echoed around the ruined hall, bouncing from shattered column to splintered beam. Wulf’s hands trembled as he surveyed the aftermath. Splashes of color marked where banners once hung, now torn away by fire and chaos. He remembered faces—Gareth’s crooked smile, Yara’s bright eyes—now only ghosts in his mind.

‘Why?’ he asked, voice barely more than a breath.

The figure beside him, hunched in a ragged cloak, gave no reply. They had said little since the storm. Their presence was comforting, but also strange; Wulf could not recall when they had arrived.

A distant rumble shook the ground. Wulf forced himself upright. He was alive, and that meant something. He had to carry the stories of those who hadn’t made it.

‘Come on,’ he said. ‘We can’t stay here.’

The figure nodded, and together they moved out into the wild unknown, Wulf glancing over his shoulder only once. The ruins faded behind him, but the memories would not. He walked on, the sole survivor, but never truly alone.

He emerged with the cloth bag, holding it aloft until his mother nodded to indicate he had gotten the right one. The morning sun filtered through the cracked windows of the market as he made his way back, weaving between stalls of bright fruit and loud vendors. His mother’s eyes, stern and searching, softened just a little as he handed the bag over. She opened the drawstring and peered inside, her fingers brushing the smooth stones nestled within. He shifted his weight, unsure if he should have asked what they were for. But she only smiled, the kind of smile that carried secrets. 

“Come,” she said, leading him down the narrow alley behind the spice merchant. 

He followed, clutching the empty bag, listening to the stones clack together in his mother’s hand. When they reached the riverbank, she knelt and arranged the stones in a careful pattern. The water shimmered, reflecting the world upside down. With a quiet word, she tapped the center stone. A ripple spread, and suddenly he saw shapes moving beneath the surface—things he’d only heard about in bedtime stories. His mother looked back at him, her eyes bright. “Ready?” she whispered.

She smiled, exhaustion and hope mingling in her chest, and decided she might just go for a walk before the world woke up.

Nora shifted uneasily, pulling her brother closer to the wall as another battered truck screeched to a stop at pump three. The sun baked the cracked pavement, and the smell of gasoline hung thick in the air. Their mother was still inside the store, arguing with the cashier over a lottery ticket, leaving them exposed, vulnerable, and far too visible for Nora’s liking.

A radio crackled from inside one of the cars, something about a chase on the highway. Nora’s heart thudded. She tried to distract her brother, telling him a story about dinosaurs and rocket ships, but her eyes never left the entrance, watching for the flash of headlights or the glint of a bumper that spelled danger. The world felt unpredictable, like at any moment a reckless driver could shatter the fragile safety of their waiting place. When their mother finally emerged, clutching her ticket, Nora let out a breath she hadn’t realized she’d been holding. The danger, for now, had passed, but she knew that in this world, safety was never guaranteed.

Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows. The corridor is lit by a flickering neon bulb, casting strange shadows that seem to dance along the walls. My footsteps echo against the cracked tiles, a nervous rhythm that matches the thumping in my chest. I can feel Michaela behind me—close enough that I sense her presence, but far enough that I can’t quite guess her intentions.

I reach the door at the end of the hall, its paint peeling in long strips. My hand hesitates on the knob. Behind me, Michaela exhales sharply, a sound somewhere between impatience and concern. I glance back, searching her face for a sign: anger, fear, hope. But her eyes are as guarded as ever.

"Ready?" I ask, my voice barely above a whisper.

She nods, the gesture quick and tense. Together, we step through the door. The world on the other side is nothing like I expected—drenched in color and sound, chaotic and alive. For the first time, I see a flicker of emotion cross Michaela’s features: wonder, maybe, or relief. Whatever it is, I think I understand her a little better now.

I try to read Michaela’s face again, but she keeps her expression carefully neutral, lips set and eyes distant. We descend the steps together, shoes creaking against the ancient wood. Halfway down, she pauses and glances at me, just a flicker of something—regret? Fear?—before she turns away again.

When we reach the foyer, the silence is heavy. Michaela finally speaks, voice low and trembling. "You’re sure you want to do this?" she asks.

I nod, unable to find words. Whatever lies behind the cellar door, I know I can’t face it alone. Michaela’s unreadable look softens, just a little, and with a sigh, she reaches for the handle. The darkness beyond seems to swallow us whole.

instance_metrics.response: But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh. That’s what I learned standing in the middle of the empty playground, my scarf pulled tight, watching the leaves spin across the cracked asphalt. I remembered the way we used to swing here, how laughter would bounce off the monkey bars and spiral up into the sky. Now, even the rusted slide seemed to droop under the weight of memory. Still, I came every Tuesday afternoon, clutching a thermos of too-hot tea and a notebook with blank pages. I’d tell myself I was waiting for inspiration, but really, I was waiting for her. The ache pressed harder when the sun dipped low, until I noticed a small voice humming from the sandbox. A girl, maybe six, digging with a stick. She glanced up, flashed a gap-toothed smile, and offered a daisy chain. I accepted, and for the first time in months, I managed a real laugh. Not because the ache was gone, but because, for a moment, someone had reached across it. And that was enough to start again.

Maybe sadness would be my companion for a while, but with Miso by my side, I realized that laughter, however faint, was still possible.

instance_metrics.response:
Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.’

The wind whipped through the shattered timbers, carrying the scent of smoke and salt. Wulf’s boots crunched on blackened stones as he surveyed the ruin of what once was home. He tried to remember faces—his brother’s laughter, the way his mother braided her hair—but the images slipped through his mind like water. All around him, the world was silent except for the distant cry of gulls.

He knelt at the threshold of the house, fingers trailing through the ashes. ‘Why me?’ he whispered, not expecting an answer.

A shape stirred in the shadows. The old woman, her back bent like the crescent moon, hobbled forth. ‘Because you listened to the river,’ she said, her voice as brittle as dried leaves. ‘You heard its warning and fled.’

Wulf clenched his fists. Survival felt like betrayal. ‘What do I do now?’

The woman’s eyes glittered, catching the last rays of sun. ‘Now you remember. Now you build.’

Wulf rose, the burden of memory heavy on his shoulders. With the ruins behind him, he walked toward the sea, searching for a new beginning.

instance_metrics.response:
Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.’

He stared out over the silent valley, once bright with laughter and song. Now, the only voices were the wind and the crows. The figure beside him—she would not give her name—leaned on a staff carved with runes Wulf couldn’t read.

‘There must be others,’ he said, desperate. ‘Someone hiding, or lost?’

The woman shook her head. ‘The fire spared no one, save you. The old magic is fickle.’

Wulf dropped to his knees, fingers digging into the scorched earth. He wanted to scream, to rage, but the weight of loss pressed the air from his lungs. ‘Why me?’

She crouched beside him, her cloak brushing ash. ‘The world does not choose for fairness. But it does choose for purpose. You have a path yet to walk.’

Wulf looked at his hands, blackened with soot. If he was to be the last, he would not let their memory vanish in smoke. He stood, shoulders squared against the emptiness, and began to walk—one survivor, carrying the story of a lost world.

The silence pressed in, heavy and absolute. Wulf’s heart thudded as he stepped over the mossy threshold, eyes darting to the corners where shadows pooled like spilled ink. The halls were empty—no laughter, no clatter of wooden bowls, only the echo of his own ragged breath.

He turned to the old man who’d delivered the news. ‘What now? I have nothing left.’

The old man’s gaze was sorrowful but steady. ‘You have life. That is more than most. The woods will need you. The river will call.’

Wulf’s hands trembled as he gripped the frame of the door. He looked out at the ruined village, the fields overtaken by wildflowers and weeds. In the far distance, a wolf howled—lonely, defiant. Gathering his courage, Wulf stepped outside, the taste of loss bitter in his mouth, but a spark of something—hope, perhaps—flickered in his chest. The world was empty, but it was his to fill again.

The forest, once alive with the shouts and songs of his kin, stood still as a painting beneath the bruised twilight. But only silence replied, thick and unyielding. His companion, a crow with ragged feathers perched on a bent branch, cocked its head. ‘You have a choice, Wulf. You can bury your story here, or you can carry it beyond these woods.’

‘The wind listens. The rivers remember. Even the stones have ears, if you’re patient enough.’

Wulf stood, brushing dirt from his knees. The crow flared its wings and leapt into the sky. With a final glance at the empty clearing, Wulf set his feet on an unknown path, the weight of memory his only companion, and the hope that somewhere, someday, his story might find a listener.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The echo of those words trembled in the ruined hall, where dust motes spun in the slanted light. Wulf’s boots crunched on broken glass as he moved forward, every step a memorial to those who had not made it. Around him, the remnants of banners fluttered in the occasional draft, their sigils half-burned and forgotten.

He knelt beside the great oak table, now splintered and blackened, his fingers tracing a familiar carving—a wolf’s head, his family’s mark. The others’ laughter seemed to haunt the air, ghosts of a time before the siege.

‘You must keep moving,’ the old healer urged, voice quivering but resolute. ‘They will come again. They always do.’

Wulf hesitated, glancing once more at the devastation. The weight of survival pressed upon him, heavier than any blade. As he rose, he pressed his palm against the carved wolf, whispering a vow. If he was truly the only one left, then their memory would live on through him. He would endure. He would not let them be forgotten.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The words hung in the air, heavy as ash. The village square was unrecognizable, charred beams jutting from the earth like broken teeth. Wulf’s heart pounded in the hush, his gaze searching for any sign of movement among the debris.

He knelt beside what had been the baker’s stall, brushing aside soot until his fingers found the cold, round edge of a loaf. The irony bit at him—bread, now useless, in a world empty of mouths. He looked up at the old woman, the only other soul he’d seen since the fires. Her eyes were hollow.

‘Why me?’ he whispered. She didn’t answer. Perhaps she wasn’t really there, just another ghost among many.

Wulf stood, the silence pressing in. He felt the weight of the world’s end, and yet, in the distant woods, a bird began to sing. He strode toward the sound, carrying nothing but hope and the memory of what once was. The future would be his to carve, alone but alive.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

He stared into the rippling water at his feet, the moon’s reflection fractured by every tremor in his hands. Around them, the woods pressed close, thick with the memory of voices now silenced. The old man beside him coughed, a dry sound that seemed to belong to another world.

‘You’ll have to go back,’ the old man said. ‘Tell them what happened here.’

Wulf shook his head, unwilling to become the sole bearer of tragedy. Yet as dawn bled into the sky, he knew there was nothing else he could do. He stood, brushing dirt from his knees, and took one last look at the clearing where so many dreams had ended. He would carry the truth forward, his burden and his offering to those lost in the dark.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked, peering through the grimy window at the flickering light in the workshop. The old man—her neighbor—was hunched over a table, hammering at something she couldn’t quite see. She remembered when her father had done the same, crafting tiny schooners from driftwood after supper, his hands nimble despite the cold.

“No, not ships,” her grandmother replied, voice low. “He’s making lanterns. For the festival.”

Alie frowned. Ships seemed more important, more real. Lanterns floated for a night, then burned out or drifted away. But ships—ships could carry you somewhere else.

Later, as dusk fell, she crept closer. The workshop door was ajar. Inside, the old man carefully painted a glowing hull onto a paper lantern. He looked up, meeting her gaze. “Come help me,” he said with a smile.

Alie hesitated, then entered. Together, they shaped fragile ships with paper sails, ready to drift on the dark water. That night, as she watched their fleet of lanterns bobbing on the bay, Alie realized: sometimes, you build ships not to leave, but to remember why you stay.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. She could hear the low thud of hammers and the rasp of saws from the shed behind the house.

“No, not ships,” her brother replied, not looking up from his sketchbook. “He’s building wings.”

Alie frowned and pressed her face to the cold glass. Through the fogged window, she saw Uncle Jonas bent over a great frame, feathers and canvas strewn around him. Not ships, but something that might fly.

“But why wings?” she whispered.

“Because he doesn’t want to sail away,” her brother said, voice soft. “He wants to see above it all. To look down on the water, not cross it.”

Alie watched Jonas stretch his new creation, testing the strength with careful hands. The thought of flying, of seeing her world from high above, sent a thrill through her chest. That night, while the house slept, she dreamed of skimming clouds and gliding over waves—a ship, but for the sky.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked, voice muffled by her scarf as they trekked past the frozen harbor.

Mara shook her head, her breath rising in tiny clouds. “No. He’s building something else. Something for the thaw.”

Alie paused, curiosity piqued. They’d all heard the rumors—how Old Ferris never spoke, never let anyone into his rickety boathouse. But each spring, something new appeared at the docks. Last year, it was a glider shaped like a heron. The year before, a mechanical whale that sputtered and swam.

As they approached the boathouse, a strange melody drifted out—a music box, or maybe wind chimes. Through the cracks, Alie glimpsed Ferris hunched over blueprints, surrounded by gears and sails.

"Maybe it’s not a ship," Mara whispered, "but a way to travel somewhere we can’t even imagine."

A thrill ran through Alie. Maybe this spring, Ferris would unveil a vessel to take them farther than any ship ever could—across ice, air, or even dreams.

He beckoned her closer, lifting the tarp’s edge. Alie gasped. A sleek, silvery frame gleamed in the lamplight—wings stretching wide, wheels tucked beneath.

“It’s an airplane,” her father said softly. “We’re going to fly.”

Alie’s heart fluttered faster than any ship’s sail. She’d spent her childhood on the docks, watching hulls rise and launch, but flying—soaring above the sea—felt like magic. She traced her fingers over the cool metal, imagining clouds and sun on her cheeks.

“Can I help?” she whispered.

Her father nodded. “Of course.”

And as the stars blinked awake outside, Alie realized some journeys didn’t start on water, but in the wide, waiting sky.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked, her voice nearly drowned by the shrieks of gulls overhead. She watched her older cousin, Rian, who knelt by the tide pools with a pile of driftwood and a battered toolbox. But Rian only smiled, eyes glinting with a secret.

“Not ships,” he said, slotting together odd pieces of metal and glass. “I’m building a message.”

Alie frowned, unsure. “A message?”

Rian nodded. He held up a strange contraption—a box with a sail of mirror shards and a tiny bell. “When the sun hits it right, the light will bounce across the bay, and the bell will ring. If someone’s out there, they’ll know we’re waiting.”

Alie stared at the shimmering device. It wasn’t a ship, but it could carry a hope farther than any vessel. She helped him plant it high on a rock, and together they waited for the tide—and for the bell to chime, echoing across the endless blue, carrying their message to the unknown.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. 

Her mother paused, wiping flour from her hands. “In his own way, dear. Not with timber and nails, but with dreams.”

Alie frowned, peering out the window at the neighbor’s shed, where hammering echoed in the dusk. She remembered the old man’s stories of the sea, of distant lands and wild winds. But the boy—her classmate, quiet and always drawing—what kind of ships could he build?

That night, Alie crept across the lawn. The shed door creaked open and there, amid blueprints and scattered wood, sat the boy. He didn’t look up. Instead, he painted a swirling hull on parchment, sails billowing with stars.

Alie watched, breathless. Each brushstroke seemed to summon a world. Oceans bled from the ink, ships danced on the walls. He smiled, finally, at his silent audience.

“I build ships,” he whispered, “to sail where I cannot go.”

Alie understood, then. Not all ships were meant for water. Some sailed the imagination, carrying hopes beyond the horizon.

Grandfather glanced up from his whittling, the small wooden hull in his hands. “Not ships, exactly. Something else.”

Alie’s curiosity prickled. She tiptoed around the shed, peering through the dusty window. Her brother, Finn, was hunched over a table, surrounded by scattered gears and clockwork parts. Instead of planks and sails, he assembled brass cogs, tiny pistons, and delicate wires.

Alie slipped inside, the scent of oil and sawdust mingling in the air. “What are you making?” she asked.

Finn grinned, holding up a small, mechanical boat. Its wheels spun as he wound a key. “A ship for the land,” he said. “One that sails on wheels, powered by springs.”

Alie’s eyes widened as the contraption rolled across the floor, clicking and whirring. Grandfather chuckled. “Every generation builds their own kind of ship, Alie. Some for water, some for wind, and some for dreams.”

Alie smiled, watching Finn’s invention sail away—proof that ships could journey anywhere, if only you dared to build them.

She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. His devotion felt like a warm coat on a bitter night, always offered, never quite fitting. She watched him in the kitchen, humming as he prepared her favorite meal, every gesture a quiet declaration. She memorized his smile, the way his eyes sparkled when she laughed—even if the joke wasn’t funny.

Still, there was a chasm inside her, a silence that echoed between his words and her heart. She tried to bridge it with gratitude, with kindness, with small gifts and gentle touches. But her affection felt borrowed, like shoes a size too small. She wondered if love could be learned, or if it was an instinct she had somehow missed.

One evening, as the sun melted behind the rooftops, he took her hand. "You don’t have to love me the way I love you," he said quietly. "Just love me your way."

She squeezed his hand, feeling something new spark in the hollow. Maybe love wasn’t always mirrored. Maybe it grew, awkward and real, wherever it was planted.

instance_metrics.response:
She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. Every morning, his gaze lingered with the warmth of a sunrise, and every night, his words wrapped around her like a lullaby. She tried to echo his affection—leaving notes, cooking meals, laughing at jokes she didn’t find funny—but the feeling never matched his. Hers was a muted symphony to his vibrant chorus.

She read books about love, searching for instructions. She watched him with their friends, hoping to pick up clues in the way he listened, the way he cared. Yet, every attempt felt awkward, forced, like reciting lines from a play she hadn’t rehearsed.

One evening, as the first raindrops tapped the window, she confessed her uncertainty. He listened, then smiled softly. "I never wanted you to love me the same way," he said. "I just wanted you to love me in your way."

Relief bloomed in her chest. Maybe her love wasn’t a grand gesture or a poetic phrase. Maybe it was simply showing up, again and again, learning a new kind of language together.

She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. It wasn’t that she didn’t care for him; she did, deeply. She responded with smiles, with gratitude, with a hand resting on his knee, but she wondered if he ever noticed the difference.

One night, as the city lights flickered beyond their window, she tried to explain. "I want to love you more," she said, her voice barely above a whisper. He reached for her hand and squeezed it gently.

"You love me the only way you know how," he replied, "and that’s enough for me." For the first time, she let herself believe it might be true. Perhaps love wasn’t measured in intensity, but in honesty. And in that honesty, she found a quiet kind of peace.

He dreamed aloud of eternity; she struggled to imagine next week.

One dusk, she wandered outside, kneeling in the damp grass beside the wildflowers. She pressed her palms to the earth, uncertain what to say or do. Suddenly, she realized love might not always be a blazing sun—sometimes, it was a seed, uncertain but full of possibility. She gathered a handful of petals and pressed them into a book, her own small gesture of hope.

When she gave him the pressed petals, she couldn’t find the words to explain. But he smiled, eyes shining, as though he understood the language of hesitant hearts. She realized love could be quiet and clumsy, yet real. Maybe she’d never love him like he loved her, but she could love him, in her own slow, blooming way.

I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. Lately, I’ve started to think they know I’m watching. It sounds ridiculous, but sometimes, in the videos, a whale will roll over, stare straight into the camera, and there’s this look—like it wants to say something. 

Last week, someone posted a video of a blue whale slapping its tail. The caption read just “Monday vibes.” I commented a blue heart, but the next morning, I woke up to a DM request from an account called @whale_hello_there. No posts, no followers, just a profile pic of a whale’s eye. The message said: "Meet us at the pier. Midnight."

I didn’t go. Of course not. But now, every time I scroll, the whales seem closer. Their eyes follow me. And sometimes, in the dead quiet of the night, I hear a deep, distant call echoing through my walls. I think I’m being summoned.

When he finished his tale, the pub was silent save for the wind, and I wondered if the faerie kingdom’s doors ever truly closed behind those who wander in.

instance_metrics.response: The internet and the millions of computers associated with it, the virtual reality that therein exists and that will become more vivid in the years ahead, is not a reality. At least, not the reality that Lila remembered from her childhood. She sat in her dim apartment, the only light emanating from her neural visor, casting ghostly shapes on the walls. Online, she was a renowned architect, shaping impossible cities in worlds that felt more real than the cracked pavement outside her window. But when she peeled off the visor, the silence pressed in. The friends, the accolades, the laughter—all gone. People she knew in the virtual world walked past her on the street, their eyes glazed, their minds still tethered to digital realms. Lila wondered: if everyone chose the dream over the world, would the world wither away? Or was the dream, built on fragile code and fleeting attention, the thing that would fade when the last server blinked out? She reached for her visor again, hesitated, and then opened her window. The city was quiet, but a bird sang. She listened, just for a moment, to something no algorithm could ever conjure.

Or so Mara believed, until the day she met Eon. He was just another username in a crowded forum, a string of clever jokes and digital artwork that caught her attention. They built whole worlds together—castles on distant planets, forests glowing with bioluminescence—all made of code and imagination. One evening, as thunder rolled outside her window, Mara realized she knew Eon better than most people she saw every day. Was this not real? The warmth in his typed words, the laughter they shared, the late-night confessions—they felt as tangible as the rain tapping her window. She wondered if reality might be less about atoms and more about moments, connections, and meaning, regardless of the medium. Mara closed her laptop, her heart racing. The storm outside was real, but so, she decided, was the world she and Eon had made.

One night, as Jiro wandered through a virtual city of perpetual twilight, he met a stranger who challenged him: "Why do you return to this place if you know it isn't real?" Jiro hesitated. Maybe, he thought, the line between real and unreal is not so sharp. Perhaps the light of a screen, the echo of a voice through a headset, and the comfort of distant companionship were just as valid as the world outside his window. Maybe, Jiro realized, reality was simply what we chose to believe in.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The wind carried ashes through the broken timbers of the hall. Wulf stood in the remains, his boots crunching over charred bones and splintered shields. He pressed his hand to his chest, feeling the stillness inside—no heartbeat but his own. The others’ laughter, their voices, even their despair: all gone, snuffed out in a single night by fire and betrayal.

He knelt and sifted through the debris, searching for something—anything—to prove he was not alone. A silver ring, twisted by heat, caught his eye. He remembered Edda’s laughter as she spun it on her finger. Now he slipped it into his pocket, a relic of a vanished world.

Wulf stared at the empty sky, the silence pressing in. Survivor’s guilt coiled inside him. Was he chosen, or simply unlucky? He wandered to the edge of the ruins, each step heavy with memory. Beyond, the wild moors beckoned, cold and indifferent.

‘Then I suppose I must carry the story,’ he whispered to the wind, and began to walk, leaving the ashes behind.

He had never wanted to be a hero. Survival was a cruel crown, one that pressed hard on his brow. ‘Why me?’ he whispered, hoping for an answer in the silence. But there was only the hush of wind and the faint drip of water from the ruined roof.

Wulf stumbled to what had been the village square. There, he knelt, fingers digging into the cold mud. He wept—not for himself, but for all the laughter he would never hear again, the faces now lost to smoke and shadow. ‘It appears so,’ the voice had said, but Wulf understood now: the living must bear the burden of memory. Rising, he turned toward the uncertain dawn, determined to remember and to endure.

He pressed his palm to his heart, half-expecting to feel nothing. Yet it thudded on, stubborn and bewildered. He wondered if the world would even notice he had survived. The old chronicles spoke of heroes or monsters as sole survivors, but Wulf felt neither heroic nor monstrous—only hollow, a vessel for sorrow and memory.

He knelt by a toppled stone, its inscription half-swallowed by soot, and whispered the names of those he’d lost. The sky was beginning to lighten. With trembling hands, he gathered a handful of earth, letting it sift through his fingers. If he was truly the last, then he would be the world’s witness, the lone voice to remember. He stood and, with a final look at the ashes, began walking toward whatever future awaited the only one who lived.

“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. Her voice quivered with a mix of hope and disbelief as she peered out over the fog-shrouded cove. The answer came as a whisper from behind, as if the wind itself spoke. “He is, but not like the ones you know.”

Alie turned to see her grandmother, eyes gleaming with secrets. “What do you mean?”

The old woman beckoned her closer, leading her behind the dunes to where strange shapes lay half-buried in sand—vessels with hulls of glass, sails of shimmering thread. “These are dreamships. Your brother builds them at night, from memories and wishes.”

Alie reached out, touching a glowing prow. Visions flickered in her mind: distant lands, lost friends, the ache of longing. “Where do they go?” she whispered.

“Anywhere you need to be,” her grandmother replied, “if you’re brave enough to board.”

Alie hesitated, then climbed aboard the nearest ship. The world shivered. The sails billowed, catching winds she could not see. As the dreamship lifted from the earth, Alie understood—her brother built ships to carry hearts home, no matter how far they’d wandered.

instance_metrics.response:
"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked. The old harbor master wiped his brow, squinting past the sun-bleached docks. "He is, but not the kind you remember."

Alie followed the man’s gaze to the far end of the pier, where her brother knelt beside a strange frame of copper and vine. It didn’t look seaworthy. In fact, it didn’t look like a ship at all. It looked like a bird’s skeleton, half-constructed and far too delicate for the churning waters below.

"He said he’s making ships that fly," the harbor master muttered, half to himself. "Said the sea’s not enough for him anymore."

Alie watched her brother’s fingers dance, weaving feathers between the copper ribs. She remembered their childhood, building rafts to escape imaginary pirates. Now, he seemed to be chasing something more elusive—the wind itself.

Later, when she asked him why, he only smiled. "Because sometimes," he said, "the world is too small for the ships we dream of."

That night, as the first windship leapt from the dock into the starlit sky, Alie understood: some journeys begin where the sea ends.

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked. The answer was slow in coming, the way it always was when her father was deep in thought. He stared at the blueprints scattered across the worktable, lines of ink twisting into impossible curves.

"Not ships," he finally said, "not in the way you mean."

Alie frowned, approaching the table. There were hulls and masts, but also wheels and wings. "Then what are they?"

He traced a finger along the edge of a design. "They’re vessels for crossing boundaries. Some for water, some for land, and some—maybe—for the sky."

She blinked, trying to imagine it. "Flying ships?"

He smiled, the same mischievous grin he’d had when he first taught her to sail. "Why not? There are places the sea can’t reach."

Alie looked at the scattered plans and, for the first time, realized her father’s dreams went far beyond the horizon. Maybe, if she was brave enough, she could help him build them.

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked. Her mother nodded, her gaze fixed on the distant silhouette at the edge of the water. "He always was drawn to things that could carry him away."

Alie kicked at the sand, watching the tide nibble at her toes. "But he never said goodbye."

The wind carried the faint clink of tools from the makeshift dock. Planks lay scattered, some half-shaped, others still rough. Alie’s brother worked silently, hands deft and sure, fitting pieces together not with nails, but with careful knots of rope.

"Maybe he’s not leaving for good," her mother said softly. "Maybe he’s building a way to come back."

Alie squinted through the morning light, imagining the ship whole, its sails unfurled and ready for the world. She wondered if, one day, she’d be brave enough to build her own and follow wherever the water led.

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked. The question hung in the air, mingling with the scent of salt and ozone. Her uncle grinned wryly, gesturing to the old shed at the edge of the estuary. "Ships, yes, but not for the sea. Come see for yourself."

Inside, the dim light revealed not hulls or sails, but small wooden vessels perched atop spindly stilts, their undersides fitted with glass jars and copper wires. On a battered workbench, blueprints depicted ships floating not on water, but above it—hovering, gliding, dancing over tidal marshes like delicate insects.

Alie’s eyes widened. "What are these for?"

"For the places water can’t reach," her uncle replied, his voice tinged with mischief. "When the tides rise too high or the mudflats stretch too far—these will carry us. Not away from here, but further in. To hidden coves and secret inlets, where the ordinary ships can’t go."

Alie touched a glass jar, feeling the potential hum beneath her fingers. Maybe, she thought, building ships wasn’t just about leaving—it was about discovering new ways to stay, to belong, to explore the forgotten corners of home.

Outside, the first star appeared—a quiet witness to her transformation. She reached for it, silently thanking the chaos that had knocked her down, only to make room for the light now flooding in.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. His silhouette, framed against the window’s pale morning light, betrayed nothing. The room smelled of dust and old wood, and the silence pressed at Liza’s nerves. She steadied her voice. 

‘We need to give them a chance. You know as well as I do that they’ve already suffered enough.’

Kasim’s eyes flicked to the floorboards. He traced a boot over a crack, as if searching for an answer buried beneath. ‘It’s not our decision,’ he said quietly. ‘Orders are orders.’

Liza walked to the map pinned on the wall, her finger tracing the red lines. ‘Someone has to draw the line, Kasim. If we don’t—who will?’

He let out a slow breath. ‘You’re stubborn. Maybe that’s what we need now.’

Outside, a child’s laughter drifted through the cracked window. Liza’s resolve hardened. ‘I’ll speak for them at the council. I won’t let them be split apart.’

Kasim finally looked up and nodded. ‘Then I’ll stand with you.’

instance_metrics.response:
Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He looked away, focusing on the faded posters flapping on the shelter’s wall. ‘You say that every week, Liza. But it’s not up to us. The list comes down, and we follow it.’

She pressed her palms to the table, knuckles whitening. ‘If we keep saying it, maybe someone will listen. Maybe the right person will notice.’

Kasim’s mouth twisted into something like a smile. ‘And if they don’t? If tomorrow, they take the children and load them onto the bus? What then?’

Liza shook her head, resolute. ‘I’ll stand in front of the bus. I’ll make a scene. I’ll make them see what they’re doing.’

Thunder rumbled in the distance, rattling the glass. Kasim leaned in, his voice a whisper. ‘Just be careful, Liza. They don’t like anyone getting in the way.’

She smiled, but there was no humor in it. ‘Then they’ll see I’m not going anywhere.’

instance_metrics.response:
Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He glanced at the stack of forms, the ink smudged from hurried signatures. ‘It isn’t up to you, you know that.’

She took a breath, willing her voice not to shake. ‘It’s up to someone. I can’t watch them pack their lives into suitcases again.’

Kasim sighed, rubbing his forehead. ‘You’re just making it harder for them—and for us. The process can’t be stopped.’

Liza stood, her chair scraping against the linoleum. ‘Maybe I can’t stop it. But I can bear witness. I can make them remember these people as more than names on paper.’

He looked at her, uncertainty flickering in his eyes. ‘Witnessing won’t change the outcome.’

‘It’ll change something,’ she replied, voice firm. ‘I owe them that much.’

As the hallway bell rang, Liza gathered her notes. She would not be silent. Not today.
