Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. The fire crackled between them, shadows flickering on the stone walls. ‘You’re always so sure,’ he said quietly. ‘But what if they force us?’

Liza stared at the flame. ‘Then we resist. We make it as hard as possible. We show them we’re not afraid.’

Kasim’s lips pressed together. ‘You talk like a fighter. But I’ve seen what happens to fighters.’

A gust of wind rattled the shutters. Liza’s hand trembled as she reached for his. ‘I’m scared too, Kasim. But fear doesn’t mean surrender.’

He hesitated, then took her hand. ‘If you stand, I’ll stand with you. But we might lose everything.’

She squeezed his fingers. ‘Maybe. Or maybe we keep something worth fighting for.’

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He sifted the papers on the table, lips pursed, as if the answer might be written between the lines. Outside, the steady drone of the checkpoint speakers echoed through the camp.

‘You say that like it’s a charm,’ Kasim said, finally. ‘But words don’t hold walls together.’

Liza’s gaze drifted to the window, where children chased a battered ball through puddles. ‘Maybe not,’ she murmured, ‘but silence would pull them apart faster.’

A sudden gust rattled the panes. Kasim exhaled, shoulders slumping. ‘They’ll come at dawn. You know they always do.’

She pressed her palm to the table, steady. ‘Then I’ll be here at dawn, too. I’ll be here every morning, until someone listens. Until someone sees.’

Kasim looked at her, uncertainty flickering in his eyes, but something else, too—a faint glimmer of hope. ‘You’re stubborn,’ he said.

Liza smiled, fierce and unyielding. ‘Someone has to be.’

Every night, she would wander the cliffs above Peel, searching for the shimmer of wings or the sound of lilting laughter on the wind, desperate to return, yet terrified of what she might find. When she finally vanished for good, he found her journal, pages filled with sketches of impossible flowers and tales of feasts that never ended. He said he felt her presence on stormy nights, the air thick with salt and sorrow, as if she was caught between worlds, longing for a home that never truly existed. Even now, he walks the moors at dusk, leaving offerings of honey and bread—hoping, perhaps, that the faeries will show mercy, or that his daughter might finally find rest.

I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. It started as a way to escape the endless scroll of news and influencer drama, but somewhere along the way, it became a ritual. Every morning, coffee in hand, I’d thumb through shots of barnacled gray whales breaching, or a blue whale’s fluke vanishing beneath glossy water. There was one account, though, @CetaceanDreams, that never failed to post something strange. Once, a video of a whale’s eye—close, glassy, impossibly huge—staring straight into the lens. The caption read, “What do you see?”

That night, I dreamed of the whale’s eye. It felt like falling into a blue abyss. In the following days, I noticed odd things: the sound of water sloshing behind my walls, the scent of salt in my apartment, a persistent pressure in my ears. My friends said I was imagining things. But every time I scrolled past a whale photo, I felt that eye watching me, inviting me somewhere deeper. One evening, I put my phone down and listened. Somewhere beneath the city noise, there was a low, resonant song, calling me home.

I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. My friends don’t get it, but it’s the only thing that calms me down. A few weeks ago, one account posted a live feed: a whale calf, not quite sure how to breach yet, kept flopping sideways and splashing awkwardly. There were hundreds of viewers, but only a handful left comments—mostly heart emojis and the occasional "aww."

But then, someone with the handle @deepcall posted, “Watch for the shadow.” I stared at the screen. Just as the calf dove, a massive, darker shape slid beneath it, hardly visible. Was it another whale? A shark? I couldn’t tell. I scrolled back, watching the clip again and again. The next day, @deepcall messaged me, “You saw it, right?” That night, I dreamed of the ocean—dark and endless, full of distant, moving shapes. When I woke up, my phone buzzed. Another video: the same calf, but this time, the shadow surfaced. I haven’t been able to look away since.

The chat was full of people from all over—marine biologists, artists, a retired fisherman from Maine. We started trading stories, art, even whale-inspired recipes. 

One night, someone live-streamed from a kayak. The ocean was mirror-still, the sky violet with dusk. Out of nowhere, a minke whale surfaced, exhaling a plume that caught the fading sun. The chat exploded with awe. For a moment, I felt like I was there—not just an observer, but part of some quiet congregation gathered around these ancient, breathing mysteries. Now, whenever I scroll through those accounts, I remember that night, and it feels a little less like scrolling and a little more like belonging.

Sometimes I replay the same clip—a juvenile humpback breaching, sunlight scattering off its barnacled skin—over and over, just to see the water explode and settle. 

Last month I started commenting, just emojis at first—waves, blue hearts, a whale. Then I wrote, “I wish I could see this in person.” Someone replied: “Meet us at the docks, sunrise.” I stared at the message for hours. It felt like a dare, or an invitation. I went. The boat was smaller than I expected, the water colder. But when a distant plume erupted on the horizon, I forgot about everything else. For a minute, watching a real whale breach, I belonged to the world again.

I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. At first, I shrugged and kept scrolling. But then, the whales started repeating. The same sequence, the same breach, over and over. I watched, transfixed, as a blue whale surfaced, opened its mouth, and paused. It looked straight into the camera. 

The comments were gone. The captions, gone too. My phone heated up in my hands. I tried to close the app, but it wouldn’t let me. Suddenly, my speakers crackled to life. A low, vibrating call filled the room, resonating in my bones. 

I blinked. My apartment was gone. I was underwater, weightless, surrounded by gentle giants. They drifted past, unhurried, unconcerned, as if I’d always belonged here. Maybe I do. Now, I drift too, floating through an endless feed of blue, wondering if anyone notices I’m gone.

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked.

Mora glanced up from her workbench, where slender planks curled like ribbons in her deft hands. She hesitated, the question echoing in the sawdust-thick air. "He says he’s building something better than ships," she replied, flicking a chip of wood off her apron. "Says he’s got dreams of a vessel that sails the sky instead of the sea."

Alie’s eyes widened. "A skyship?"

Mora nodded, a wry smile on her lips. "He’s got blueprints pinned to every wall in his shed. Gears and wings and sails made from silk. He’s even training the crows to follow him—says they’ll be his scouts."

Alie peered through the cracked window at the distant shed, smoke and sparks dancing against the twilight. "Do you think he’ll fly?"

Mora shrugged, but hope glimmered in her eyes. "If anyone can, it’s him. Just promise me you’ll be here when he tries."

Alie squeezed her friend’s hand, heart pounding with anticipation, as dreams of impossible journeys took flight on the evening wind.

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked.

She watched as he fastened odd metal plates to the sides, humming quietly.

Mara, her elder cousin, shook her head. "Not ships. He calls them ‘drifters’. Says they’ll float above the water, not on it. I think he’s lost his mind."

But Alie couldn’t look away. Jonas had always been strange, but she liked the way his inventions made the world feel bigger. She wanted to ask him if she could help, to touch the strange balloon he’d stitched from old canvas sails.

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked.

Grandfather’s shed groaned under the weight of secrets. Alie’s brother, Finn, had disappeared into its shadows hours ago, and the rhythmic hammering had not ceased since. She pressed her ear to the door, catching the faint scent of pine and resin.

Grandmother shuffled up behind her, a smile tugging at her lips. "Ships? No, darling. Finn’s building something for the stars."

Alie blinked. "For the stars?"

"He saw the comet last winter, remember? He believes it was a sign. He thinks if he builds a craft fine enough, light enough, it’ll catch the tail of the next one."

Alie’s heart fluttered. She pictured Finn sailing a silver vessel across midnight skies, stardust trailing behind him. It sounded impossible, but so did flying before the first bird took wing.

A soft thud came from inside; Finn’s silhouette moved behind the frosted window. Alie grinned, already planning to sneak in later. Maybe, just maybe, she’d find a way to help him chase that comet.

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked.

The question hung between them as the rain pattered softly on the greenhouse roof. Her mother didn’t answer right away, instead wiping her hands on her muddy apron and turning a seed packet over in her palm.

"Not ships, exactly," she replied at last. "He’s building something...smaller. Something that can slip between the reeds where the river narrows."

Alie pressed her forehead to the misty glass, watching her brother’s silhouette laboring beneath the willow, piecing together thin strips of cedar. "A boat for one?"

Her mother nodded. "He wants to see what’s upstream—past the bend, where no one’s gone before. Says the real adventure begins where the river gets too wild for big ships."

Alie smiled, imagining her brother drifting towards the unknown, bold and hopeful. Maybe, when he came back, he’d have stories to fill this rainy afternoon. Or maybe, she thought, there’d be room in that little boat for her, too.

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked.

Uncle Tarn didn’t look up from the heap of copper coils and glass bulbs spread across his table. Instead, he grinned, eyes twinkling behind foggy spectacles. "Ships? Only in a manner of speaking, Alie. I’m building a vessel, yes, but not for water."

She crept closer, curiosity pulling her in. The blueprints scattered around looked nothing like the sleek hulls down at the docks. This one had wings, strange wheels, and a crystal sphere at its heart.

"It’s for the dreamsea," Tarn whispered conspiratorially. "Where the sky is purple and the clouds swim like whales. I’ll chart new constellations, bring back bottles of starlight."

Alie’s breath caught. "Can I come?"

He nodded, solemn as a captain. "Every good vessel needs a first mate."

Together they gathered wire and dreams, preparing to launch at midnight, when the world was quiet and the air shimmered with possibility. As the clock chimed, Alie climbed aboard the impossible craft, ready to sail not on water, but into realms only the bravest dared imagine.

The lower offices were sufficiently warren-like that she could sneak upstairs without being observed. Each narrow corridor twisted unexpectedly, and the walls were lined with filing cabinets that seemed to have sat undisturbed for decades. She padded quietly, passing the copy machine and the break room where the smell of burnt coffee hung in the stagnant air. Her heart pounded as she glanced over her shoulder, but the only sounds were the hum of fluorescent lights and the distant murmur of voices from the main lobby. 

She reached the foot of the stairwell, its ancient metal steps creaking underfoot. The second floor was reserved for the partners and, more importantly, the file she needed. She crept past the frosted glass doors, glancing at the nameplates: Hargrove, Lin, Patel. Finally, she found the office marked "Records." Inside, the file sat on the desk, exactly as her source had promised. She grabbed it, tucking it into her coat just as footsteps echoed in the hallway. Holding her breath, she ducked behind a cabinet, clutching the file to her chest, praying her luck would hold.

The lower offices were sufficiently warren-like that she could sneak upstairs without being observed. The maze of cubicles, stacks of old files, and flickering light bulbs provided cover for anyone nimble enough to use them. She moved quickly, her footsteps muffled by the threadbare carpet, pausing only when a stray chair threatened to betray her with a creak. Her destination was the director's office—a place few dared to visit after hours.

When she reached the stairwell, she glanced back, half-expecting to see a pair of suspicious eyes. But the only witness was the dusty clock ticking away on the wall. Up the stairs she went, heart pounding, fingers curled around the tiny flash drive in her pocket. She recalled the whispered instructions: "Top drawer on the left. Don’t stay longer than you have to."

On the upper landing, she hesitated. Shadows stretched down the hallway, and the door to the director's office was ajar. Had someone beaten her here? She steeled herself and stepped forward, determined to finish what she’d started—whatever secrets waited inside.

I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. I don’t know when it started—maybe in the dead of winter, when my apartment felt claustrophobic and I needed to see something big and free and blue. Anyway, the algorithm caught on, and soon my feed was nothing but whales: humpbacks turning slow and deliberate, orcas slicing through kelp forests, the endless ballet of flukes and spray. I’d lose hours to it, half-awake at midnight, thumb scrolling as if by muscle memory. 

One night, I saw a live stream—just the ocean at first, dark and shimmering, then a fin, a breach, a spout. The comments scrolled by: “Did you see that flip?” “Look at the baby!” I felt myself leaning in, as if I could fall through the glass of my phone into that cold, wild place. For a moment, it was like I wasn’t alone. For a moment, I was drifting too, weightless, the echo of whale song buzzing in my ears.

I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. It started as a joke—I thought it was hilarious, the sheer majesty of these animals juxtaposed with captions like “Monday mood” or “big stretch.” But over time, it became something else. I’d watch the videos late at night, volume turned up, letting the low moans and chirps fill my bedroom. Sometimes, I’d close my eyes and imagine I was there, floating just beneath the surface, the world above distorted and shimmering.

One day, I realized I hadn’t spoken to another person in almost a week. The whales were my company. I started to narrate my life in whale terms: “Today I breached out of bed.” “Lunch was a krill-level disappointment.” It was absurd, but comforting. Eventually, I started to dream in blue and gray, in the slow grandeur of giants. When I finally did go outside again, I found myself scanning the horizon for a plume, a tail, some sign that I wasn’t alone in my love for the deep.

instance_metrics.response: If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. He never asked me to, not really. It started with a few scribbled edits on his second draft, my notes in the margins, suggestions for better dialogue. Now, I spend evenings hunched over the battered manuscript, deciphering his handwriting, weaving his scattered ideas into a story I hope he’ll recognize. The irony isn’t lost on me: I fix his characters’ broken relationships while ours unravels in the silence. Some nights, I catch him watching me through the doorway, his gaze flickering with gratitude or guilt—I can’t tell which. Maybe, when the book is finished, we’ll finally speak again. Or maybe I’ll just keep writing, waiting for a sentence that brings him back to me.

instance_metrics.response: If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. It’s not exactly ghostwriting; he calls it collaboration, though my name will never appear on the cover. I pore over his handwritten notes, decoding half-lucid dreams and cryptic metaphors, while he paces the kitchen, muttering lines under his breath like incantations. Sometimes, I wonder if I’m writing about us—the way his protagonist leaves, the way the lover waits. I slip hints of our life into the dialogue, small confessions he may never notice. By the time he joins me, coffee in hand, I’ve lived a dozen secret lives in the margins of his pages. I smile, hand him the latest draft, and watch as he reads, searching for something he can’t quite name.

Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. I had a steady job, a townhouse with sunlight spilling through bay windows, and a circle of friends who texted me every Wednesday. My husband, for all his cruel words and icy silences, never hit me. He bought me gifts—expensive ones—and sometimes, in public, he’d even hold my hand. I told myself every day that it could be worse, that others had it harder, that my bruises were invisible and therefore didn’t count. 

But privilege can be a gilded cage. My salary paid for vacations I never took, my home was filled with things I didn’t choose. I smiled in family photos, lips pressed tight, while my mind catalogued the concessions I’d made just to keep the peace. It took a while to realize that privilege didn’t erase pain; it only disguised it. When I finally packed my bags, my friends rallied. My job gave me time off. I moved into a tiny apartment and, for the first time, the sunlight felt warm. I was privileged, yes. But now, I was also free.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged.

instance_metrics.response:
Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. I could afford therapy, even if my husband sneered at the idea. My parents lived three cities away and called every Sunday, their concern barely hidden behind cheerful voices. I had a garden, wild with lavender and mint, where I could breathe when the house was too small. 

Some nights, I traced the outlines of my good fortune, cataloging the comforts others might envy: a car, a passport, the means to leave. Yet still, I stayed for years, convinced that privilege meant I didn’t have the right to complain. My wounds were subtle—a sharp word, a cold shoulder, promises broken in whispers. 

It was the garden that saved me. The slow rhythm of planting, the silent faith in roots. One morning, I left the door open and walked barefoot through dew. The sky was feathered with pink, the air sweet and new. My privilege hadn’t protected me, but it gave me the tools to rebuild. With trembling hands, I finally chose to start again, and the garden bloomed brighter than ever before.

instance_metrics.response:
Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. I could afford to escape, though it took me years to realize it. My husband’s anger was a constant thunder, but our refrigerator was always full, and I never worried about paying rent. I felt guilty for my misery, surrounded by friends who struggled with bills and single mothers who scraped by each month. 

At book clubs and brunches, I wore a mask so convincing that no one suspected the loneliness that gnawed at me every night. When I finally confessed, my sister said, "You always seemed so lucky." I suppose I was, in the ways that matter on paper, but privilege doesn’t shield you from heartbreak. Eventually, I packed my bags—designer suitcases my husband bought me to impress his colleagues—and walked out into the unknown. With every step, I felt lighter. Freedom, I realized, is a privilege too, and this time, it was one I chose for myself.

Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. My bank account was healthy, my career thriving, and my passport crowded with stamps from places most people only dream of. My husband’s words, though sharp and deliberate, never left visible scars. At parties, I wore silk and smiled, convincing the world—and sometimes myself—that everything was fine.

But privilege is a double-edged sword. It gave me the means to stay, to rationalize my suffering as a fair price for comfort and status. I worried that admitting my pain would sound ungrateful. I watched sunsets from penthouses and cried in marble bathrooms, the ache inside me echoing in the empty, echoing rooms. In the end, it was my privilege that saved me. I found the strength to leave, to rebuild, to learn that true fortune lies not in things, but in the freedom to pursue happiness. I was privileged, yes—but now, I am also whole.

She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. Each morning, she watched him make coffee, humming off-key, his devotion shining in the gentle way he set her mug on the table. She wanted to mirror that tenderness, to feel the certainty he seemed to carry so easily. But inside, her heart fluttered like a moth against a glass jar, all frantic energy and no direction. She tried: she listened, she smiled, she leaned into his touch. Yet every gesture felt borrowed, like a line read from someone else’s script. 

One rainy afternoon, she found him in the kitchen, staring out the window. "I’m sorry," she said, voice barely above a whisper. "I’m trying." He turned, his eyes full of understanding and sadness. "I know," he replied, and for the first time, she heard the tremor in his voice. In that moment, she realized love wasn’t just a feeling but a language she hadn’t learned to speak. And maybe, just maybe, if they both tried, they could invent a new one together.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. The rain slashed against the windows of the cramped office, collecting in hazy rivers on the glass. Liza’s voice trembled, not from uncertainty, but from exhaustion. They had spent weeks reviewing cases, hearing stories—children clutching threadbare toys, parents holding hope by its frayed edge.

Kasim flipped the folder closed. “You know what the directive says. We can’t take risks.”

Liza stepped forward, the flickering fluorescent light catching her determined gaze. “We can’t take hearts and tear them out, either. Not if we want to live with ourselves.”

He looked away, his jaw tense. Outside, a siren wailed, distant but insistent. For a moment, neither spoke. The silence stretched, filled with the weight of decisions yet to be made.

Finally, Kasim sighed. “You’re stubborn, Liza.”

She managed a tired smile. “I have to be. For them.”

His shoulders sagged. “I’ll see what I can do.”

As he left, Liza let herself hope—just a little—that tonight, at least, no one would be separated from the ones they loved.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He kept his gaze on the faded map pinned to the wall, tracing invisible lines, as if the borders there could shift just as easily as the rules in this room. Liza pressed her hands together, knuckles white. She could hear the muffled laughter of children from the hall.

‘You think words can change the outcome?’ Kasim murmured, voice low. ‘The order is signed.’

Liza shook her head. ‘Orders come from people. People change their minds.’

He turned, eyes tired. ‘And what if they don’t?’

She hesitated, then stepped closer, lowering her voice. ‘Then we do what we must. Quietly, if we have to.’

Kasim’s lips twitched, not quite a smile. ‘You’re not afraid, are you?’

‘Only of failing them,’ she replied.

A silence settled, thick with the weight of decisions. Outside, a door slammed. The laughter faded. Liza stood her ground, heart pounding, knowing the night ahead would demand more than words.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He reached for the mug on the cluttered table, but found it empty. He set it down, slower than necessary.

“Someone above us will decide, Liza. Not you. Not me.”

She studied him, searching for a chink in his indifference. “We’re the only ones here, right now. We can make choices.”

Kasim’s eyes flicked toward the hallway. The distant hum of conversation, the squeal of a toddler, drifted in. “You’re asking for trouble.”

“I’m asking for humanity.”

A long moment passed. The weight of a hundred stories pressed between them. Kasim exhaled, shoulders slumping. “Fine. Tonight, they stay. Tomorrow, I can’t promise.”

Liza nodded, gratitude mingling with dread. She wondered how many more tomorrows she could bargain for.

Oh, I’m great. At least, that’s what I told everyone at the reunion. Smiling through the conversations, I let the words float out of me like helium balloons, shiny and light, distracting from the weight inside my chest. Old friends laughed and clapped me on the back. It was as if my life was as polished as my shoes, as if the cracks in my voice were nothing but tricks of the light.

But when I slipped out to the garden, away from the music and the chatter, I let a sigh escape. Fireflies blinked in the dark, small and hopeful. I watched their dance and, for a moment, let my guard down. Maybe tomorrow, I thought, I could answer the question honestly. Maybe tomorrow, I could tell someone that sometimes I’m not great, and that’s okay. But for tonight, I watched the luminous insects and let the silence hold me gently, a different kind of comfort than the one I pretended to have.

Oh, I’m great. That’s what I always say, regardless of the truth. Today was no exception as I hurried through the busy streets, dodging puddles and glancing at my phone. On the screen, another message from my sister: ‘Call me. Please.’ I hesitated, then slipped the phone back into my pocket, forcing a smile at the barista as I ordered my coffee.

The sky was gray, and the city hummed with the sound of distant construction. I found a bench in the little park across from my office, sipped my coffee, and let the rain mist my face. People hurried past, umbrellas bobbing like jellyfish. I wondered if anyone else was pretending, too. Maybe we were all saying ‘I’m great’ to keep our secrets safe. As my coffee grew cold, I took a deep breath and dialed my sister back, ready—at last—to tell her how I really felt.

Oh, I’m great. That’s what I told the nurse as she checked my blood pressure, her eyes scanning the chart with practiced indifference. The truth was, I wasn’t sure how I felt anymore. My days were a blur of hospital corridors, antiseptic smells, and the low hum of concern that followed me like a shadow. But if I said I wasn’t great, what would that accomplish? More worried looks, more questions I didn’t want to answer.

So I smiled, let her tighten the cuff around my arm, and stared at the faded cartoon stickers on the wall. Outside the window, kids laughed on the playground, their voices carrying into my sterile world. For a moment, I closed my eyes and listened, letting the sound remind me of a time when ‘I’m great’ was the truth. Maybe, if I said it enough, it could be again.

Oh, I’m great. At least, I thought I was, until I found the note tucked beneath my windshield wiper. It was folded neatly, the handwriting unfamiliar but careful: ‘You are not as invisible as you think.’

I glanced around the nearly empty parking lot, heart pounding. Was it meant for me? I replayed the day in my mind—had I cut someone off in traffic, ignored a neighbor’s greeting? Or was it something deeper, a reminder that the world is full of unseen eyes and quiet observers?

Clutching the note, I climbed into my car and locked the doors. My reflection in the rearview mirror smiled back, but my thoughts raced. Maybe I wasn’t as alone as I’d believed. Maybe being seen wasn’t such a bad thing after all. I started the engine, the note trembling in my hand, and wondered who would watch what I did next.

Oh, I’m great. At least, that’s the version of me that shows up for the world—crisp shirt, quick wit, the one who always remembers birthdays and delivers clever toasts at parties. As the kettle whistled, I sat by the window, watching the slow parade of headlights below, and wondered what it might be like to say, “Actually, I’m not sure.”

In the quiet, I found a scrap of peace in the uncertainty, and for once, I let myself simply exist—no more, no less. Maybe that was its own kind of greatness, I thought, sipping tea in the company of my truest self.

Liza’s lips pressed into a determined line. ‘This time will be different. I spoke to Mrs. Pasha. She knows someone who works at the checkpoint. If we pool our papers, we can make it look like we’re all one family.’

He almost smiled, but instead looked away. ‘I saw men with flashlights down by the orchard. They’re getting closer.’

‘Then we’ll move again. Or we’ll hide them better this time.’ Liza’s eyes glinted in the dimness. ‘They want us to give up. I won’t.’

A baby whimpered from the corner. Liza went to soothe her, whispering a lullaby learned long before the soldiers came. Outside, the rain fell harder, but inside, her promise lingered—a fragile shield against the night.

Liza’s voice softened, but her resolve did not. ‘No, but they give us something to hold onto. And if we hold on together, maybe that’s enough.’

‘People make choices,’ she said, her voice steady. ‘Tonight, we choose to stay. Tomorrow, we choose again.’

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He leaned against the chipped stone wall and looked away, toward the river where the dusk had already begun to blur the outlines of the boats. They stood in silence for a moment, the murmur of the camp behind them threading through the heavy air. 

“Liza, you say that every time,” Kasim said quietly. He sounded tired, as if the words themselves cost him something. “But you know what happened last week. The trucks came at dawn. They didn’t even let the children say goodbye.”

Liza’s hands tightened on the folder she carried, papers crumpling. “I know. That’s why I won’t let it happen again.”

He laughed, bitter and low. “You think your words matter to them?”

She met his gaze, her voice trembling but steady. “Maybe not. But they matter to me. And to them.”

In the gathering shadows, Kasim shook his head. Yet when she turned away, he followed her back toward the lights—toward hope, or maybe just defiance.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged. He stooped to pick up a pebble, tossing it from palm to palm. The courtyard was still, save for the distant echo of a child’s laughter and the relentless ticking of Liza’s watch.

“Words are cheap,” Kasim said finally, voice low. “They don’t listen to us. They’ve made up their minds.”

Liza pressed her lips together. “Then we’ll make them listen.”

He shook his head, but there was a flicker in his eyes—a challenge, or maybe a plea. “And if they come tonight?”

Liza looked beyond the cracked gate, toward the cluster of tents, the makeshift lanterns swaying in the wind. “Then I’ll stand in their way. I’ll remind them what they promised.”

Kasim smiled, crooked and uncertain. “You’re stubborn.”

Night fell, and with it the certainty that nothing would be easy. But Liza’s resolve was a thread holding them all together—fragile, but unbroken.

Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. Privileged to have a safe place to retreat to when the shouting got too loud, to have friends who texted me every morning, checking in. Privileged to have a job that let me escape, even for eight hours, into a world where competence was valued and kindness was currency. I knew there were women who had less: less space, less support, less hope.

Yet every night, when I drove home, I rehearsed my answers. Why was dinner late? Why was my shirt wrinkled? Why didn’t I laugh at the right moment? The privilege was real, but so was the fear. I counted my blessings and my bruises. I clung to the knowledge that privilege is not immunity. It was a stepping stone, not a shield. It gave me options, not freedom.

One rainy Thursday, I packed my bags. My friend’s spare room became my sanctuary. I called a lawyer, found therapy, started over. Privilege, I realized, is what you do with it. For me, it became the ladder I climbed to a better life, even as I remembered those still trapped below.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged.

instance_metrics.response:
Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. I knew it every time I looked around our carefully curated apartment, every time I ordered takeout because cooking felt impossible. My job paid well, and my friends envied my vacations and designer handbags. But behind closed doors, my husband’s cutting remarks and icy silences chipped away at me, slowly and silently.

Some nights, I sat on the balcony, the city lights blinking below, and wondered how I could feel both suffocated and lucky. I had the means to leave, but guilt and fear pinned me in place. Wasn’t I supposed to be grateful for all I had? My therapist called it the golden cage. I didn’t disagree.

It took a long time, but I finally chose myself. I packed my life into two suitcases, left the keys on the counter, and walked out. My privilege didn’t erase the pain, but it gave me a path out—a place to stay, money to rebuild, friends who showed up. I carry the scars, but I also carry hope, and I know that makes me luckier than most.

instance_metrics.response:
Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. I caught myself thinking it on the morning I left, suitcase in hand, my childhood violin tucked under my arm. The privilege wasn’t in the vacations, the house, or even the reliable car I backed down the driveway. It was in the network that surrounded me—a sister who answered my call at 2am, a college friend who found me a job, and parents who, even through their disappointment, set a place for me at the table. 

The marriage had hollowed me out, left me doubting my worth. But when I finally reached my breaking point, privilege appeared in the form of options. I wasn’t trapped by circumstances, only by fear. When I finally walked into my sister’s spare room, she hugged me tight and said, “You’re safe now.”

Not everyone gets that. I think of those who stay because leaving means danger or destitution. I grieve for them, even as I gather the pieces of my own life. My privilege didn’t save me from pain, but it gave me a way out—a ladder, not a shield.

Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. I saw it in the way my mother called every evening, asking if I was okay. In the fact that I could afford therapy, even if he scoffed at it. In the moments I spent at work, surrounded by colleagues who respected me, reminding me of who I was before the constant criticism and silent treatments.

I knew my story wasn’t the worst. I didn’t worry about where I’d sleep or what I’d eat if I left. I had savings, friends who’d take me in, a passport tucked behind old birthday cards. But privilege didn’t make the nights less lonely or the mornings less heavy. It just made the path to freedom a little clearer.

When I finally walked away, I didn’t do it alone. My sister drove me to my new apartment, my boss gave me time off, my therapist answered late-night calls. I’m grateful for the net that caught me. I know not everyone gets to land softly.

Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. Not in the obvious ways, perhaps, but in the secret ones: the hidden garden behind our home. I would slip out at dawn, barefoot in the dew, and lose myself among tangled roses and hummingbirds. There, the air was different—thick with possibility, not accusations. My husband never entered; he never even noticed the way the peonies bloomed or the bees built their kingdom beneath the old bench. 

In that green refuge, I learned the language of resilience. I watched the ivy climb stone, undeterred by wind or neglect. I read borrowed books beneath the willow’s shade, their pages whispering that my world could be larger than the walls inside. I pressed seeds into soil, believing in the fragile promise of something better.

When the day came to leave, I carried with me nothing but a pocketful of lavender and the memory of sunlight on my skin. My privilege was not wealth or status, but the quiet knowledge that hope can take root even in poisoned ground—and that, with time and tending, it can blossom into a life all your own.

Reggie looked downright petrified, while Hardy had now resorted to banging a catcher’s mitt–sized metal fist on the bulkhead. The clangs echoed through the cramped escape pod, rattling the emergency rations and sending dust motes spiraling in the stale air. “It’s jammed,” Hardy grunted, his synthetic knuckles denting the steel. “We’re supposed to be out of here by now!”

Reggie’s eyes darted to the porthole. The asteroid’s surface was a blur of red dust and jagged rocks, inching ever closer with each passing second. He fumbled with the manual override, hands shaking. “I—I can’t do it, Hardy! What if it blows?”

“Then we’re space toast,” Hardy replied, a wry grin flickering on his metallic faceplate. He paused, then gently rested his heavy hand on Reggie’s shoulder. “Trust me, Reg. We’ve got one shot. On three, pull that lever.”

Reggie swallowed, nodded, and locked eyes with Hardy. “One… two… three!”

The lever groaned. The pod shuddered, then with a thunderous crack, the hatch burst open—and they tumbled into the unknown, together.

“Give it a rest, Hardy,” he whispered, but Hardy’s synthetic arm kept pounding. “If we’re stuck, we’re stuck. The ocean’s not going anywhere.”

Hardy paused, his mechanical eyes whirring, scanning the hatch. “We’re not giving up. There’s always a way out.”

From somewhere in the gloom, a faint tapping answered Hardy’s blows. Reggie froze. Hardy cocked his head and tapped again, softer this time. The response came again—three knocks, then silence. Reggie’s terror deepened as Hardy gripped his shoulder.

Reggie looked downright petrified, while Hardy had now resorted to banging a catcher’s mitt–sized metal fist on the bulkhead. The muffled alarms of the ship’s failing life-support system only made the silence between clangs more ominous. “Reggie, you’ve got to override the lockdown!” Hardy barked, his voice more hopeful than confident.

Reggie’s trembling fingers hovered over the console. “The code isn’t working! I told you—I’m an engineer, not a miracle worker!”

Hardy stopped banging, his broad metal shoulders slumping as he looked at Reggie—a mix of frustration, concern, and maybe a hint of apology in his glowing eyes. “If the code’s not working, we do it my way.”

With a screech, Hardy wedged his fist between the seams of the hatch and began to pry. Sparks flew as metal groaned. Reggie backed away, heart pounding, as the pressure alarm spiked. Then, with a final wrench, the hatch burst open. Cold night air rushed in, carrying the scent of pine and something else—freedom. Outside, the forest waited, as did the unknown.

He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. The fluorescent lights in the interrogation room had flickered just enough to unsettle him, and the rhythmic tapping of Detective Miller’s pen had become a metronome of dread. When he finally sat before the magistrate, his voice shook like autumn leaves. “I wasn’t myself last night,” he said. “They wouldn’t let me call anyone. They kept saying it would all go away if I just admitted it.”

His lawyer, a sharp-eyed woman named Edda, pressed for a review of the tapes. But the footage was somehow shorter than the time he remembered. “You can’t trust your memory when you’re exhausted,” Miller said, almost kindly. But Edda didn’t relent. She subpoenaed every scrap of evidence, found a coffee receipt timestamped hours after the supposed confession, and unearthed a silent witness: the cleaning lady, who remembered him pleading for a phone call. In the end, it wasn’t the truth that set him free, but the persistence of someone who believed his truth still mattered, even after he’d signed it away.

He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. The words echoed through the cramped holding cell, met by blank stares from fellow detainees and the weary sigh of the night guard. Nobody seemed to care whether he was guilty or not—just that paperwork was filed, forms signed, and time served. He pressed his palms to his temples, trying to remember the details of those endless hours under the buzzing lights: the officer’s low murmur, the threat of never seeing his daughter again, the pressure to just say what they wanted. 

By morning, he’d resolved to fight. He scrawled a note on a paper napkin and slid it under the cell door, hoping someone—anyone—would listen. When the public defender arrived, she was young, determined, and unimpressed by confessions extracted at three a.m. “We’ll get this sorted,” she assured him, eyes bright with the promise of justice. Even as uncertainty loomed outside the courthouse, for the first time since the nightmare began, he felt a flicker of hope. Maybe, just maybe, the truth would find its way through.

He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. The officers in the station exchanged glances, some skeptical, others annoyed, as if his reversal was a bothersome footnote in a case they had already closed in their minds. In the interview room, his hands shook as he explained, again, the sequence of threats and promises whispered to him by the detective with the tired eyes and the coffee-stained tie. 

“I just wanted to go home,” he pleaded to the recorder, voice hoarse. “I thought if I said what they wanted, I’d see my mother again.” The new lawyer, hastily assigned, took notes on a yellow pad and nodded, her lips pressed into a determined line. It was the beginning of a new fight—a battle against paperwork and perception, against the ease of a confession versus the messy truth. As she left the room, she paused, looked back, and said, “We’ll make them listen.” For the first time since his arrest, he almost believed her.

By then, the headlines had already screamed his guilt, his face flickering across television screens and newsfeeds. But in the silence of his cell, he pieced together fragments the officers hadn’t expected him to remember: the song playing on the radio, the particular brand of soda the detective spilled on the floor, and the subtle but steady pressure of a hand on his shoulder. 

He wrote a detailed account, page after page, describing every tactic used to break him. In the morning, he handed the stack to the prison chaplain, who—despite being sworn to discretion—leaked the story to an eager local reporter. Public interest reignited, and soon, protestors gathered at the courthouse, demanding justice not just for the victim, but for him. As he waited for a new hearing, his world shifted: from isolated suspect to reluctant symbol, from whispered doubts to a chorus of voices calling for truth. In that fragile moment between accusation and exoneration, he realized that his greatest confession might just be the courage to tell his story, again and again, until someone finally listened.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged.

He’d heard her say it before, always with the same firm tone, as if certainty could conjure up reality. Today, though, the air in the council chamber was brittle. The others were waiting, their faces tight with exhaustion and hope mingled like oil and water.

‘And if the orders come from higher up?’ Kasim asked, keeping his voice low.

Liza didn’t hesitate. ‘Then we fight them. We show them that these people belong together. That bonds of blood and trust are not theirs to sever.’

A murmur ran along the benches. Some were with her, he could see. Others were already defeated.

‘You’d risk everything?’ he pressed.

‘I already have,’ she replied, her eyes sharp. ‘So have they.’

He looked past her, out the window to the line of families gathered in the square—children clutching hands, mothers with anxious eyes. Maybe Liza was foolish, or maybe she was the only one left who remembered what courage looked like. He stood, nodded once, and said, ‘Then I’ll fight with you.’

instance_metrics.response:
Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged.

He’d stopped believing promises a long time ago. The walls of the processing center were thin—he could hear the children’s laughter cut short by anxious whispers, the anxious shuffle of parents’ feet. Liza’s certainty sounded like thunder in a drought.

‘You think words can stop a mandate?’ he asked, voice soft and tired.

‘I think people can,’ Liza answered, her gaze not leaving the list in her hands. ‘We’ve stalled them before. A delay, a loophole, a protest—whatever it takes, we’ll find a way.’

Kasim watched her, wondering at the stubborn fire that burned in her. He wanted to believe, just for a second, that conviction was enough. But hope was a dangerous currency here. It had cost him dearly before.

Beyond the barred window, the sun was setting, painting gold over gray. For a moment, Kasim allowed himself to imagine she was right. That tomorrow, the families would still be together, and the world would remember what mercy meant.

Liza thought this a good moment to repeat her claim: ‘These families will not be broken up.’ Kasim shrugged.

His indifference stung, but Liza pressed on, raising her voice to those gathered around the cracked table. The flickering candlelight threw uncertain shadows on their faces. ‘We have a duty,’ she continued. ‘Not just to the law, but to our own hearts.’

‘Duty?’ Kasim’s smile was thin. ‘Duty is what got us into this mess. You think officials care about our hearts?’

A hush fell. Outside, the night was restless; the wind pressed against the shutters, threatening to find a way in. Liza’s hands shook, but she gripped the worn wood for steadiness. ‘If we don’t stand for them, no one will. They’re not just names on forms, Kasim. They’re mothers, fathers, children—us.’

Kasim looked away. For a moment, Liza thought she saw sympathy flicker in his eyes, then vanish. ‘Just be careful, Liza,’ he said quietly. ‘Hope is a dangerous thing to hand out.’

But Liza had already decided—danger or not, she would not back down.

He traced a finger along the dusty windowsill, watching the rain trace lines down the glass. ‘You always say that, but it’s not up to us anymore, is it?’

‘Maybe not,’ Liza replied, her jaw set, ‘but it’s up to someone. And if no one else will stand up, then I will.’

Kasim’s eyes flickered with something like admiration, then dulled again. ‘You know what happened to the last person who tried.’

She did. The memory pressed at her, heavy and cold, but she refused to let it show. ‘That’s why I have to try harder.’

In the silence that followed, the room felt smaller, the world outside further away. Through the thin walls, the distant voices of children drifted up, laughter threading through the gloom. Liza listened to it, steeling herself, and wondered if she’d have the strength to keep her promise when the time came.

He turned away, fiddling with the radio as static filled the bunker. It was well past midnight, and the only light came from the cracked lantern between them. Liza could sense the weight in his silence, the resignation he wore like armor.

‘You know I want to believe you,’ he murmured, voice nearly lost in the hum of distant thunder. ‘But wanting doesn’t change orders.’

She moved closer, her shadow stretching across the map pinned to the wall. ‘We have the list. We know the route. There’s still time to get them out before the patrols switch.’

Kasim finally met her eyes, searching for doubt. ‘And if they catch us?’

A bitter laugh escaped him. ‘Martyrdom isn’t much comfort.’

Liza’s hand hovered over his. ‘It’s not about comfort. It’s about refusing to be the hands that tear families apart.’

The bathroom door clicked shut behind Jamie, muffling the rustle of fabric and the sharp snap of the light switch. I perched on the edge of the couch, remote in hand, thumbs fidgeting over the worn buttons. The opening notes of the show’s theme song drifted from the TV, but I paused it immediately, not wanting to start without her. 

I glanced at the sliver of light under the bathroom door. In the silence, my mind wandered: was she nervous? The new school, the new friends, maybe even the new uniform she was wrangling into. I remembered my first day, how the blazer felt stiff, how my hands shook just a little. 

A faucet ran briefly. I heard Jamie humming—off-key, but confident. I smiled, thinking about how she always sang when she was nervous, as if a song could make the world spin a little slower. The door finally creaked open, and Jamie stepped out, grinning, hair slightly damp and shirt askew. “Ready?” she asked, her voice softer than usual. I nodded, pressing play. The episode began, and for a moment, everything else faded away.

“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man pauses, sunglasses glinting in the afternoon sun, and offers a thin smile. “Subtlety is a matter of perspective,” he replies, closing the door with a soft click. 

Jonah leans casually against the lamp post, watching as the man surveys the nearly empty parking lot. “Nice neighborhood for a car like that,” Jonah adds, letting his curiosity hang in the air.

The man steps closer, the heat radiating off the Ferrari. “You know, Jonah, most people wouldn’t notice me at all. They’d only see the car.” He holds out a hand, pale and perfectly manicured. “Name’s Vincent.”

Jonah shakes it, eyebrow raised. “You move here, or just passing through?”

Vincent’s smile widens, revealing a flash of gold. “Let’s just say I’m here for something… unique.”

Jonah glances at the Ferrari again, wondering if the car or its owner is the bigger mystery. “Well, whatever it is, I hope you find it.”

Vincent laughs softly, the sound echoing off the concrete. “Oh, I always do.”

“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man glances at Jonah, lips curving into a sly grin. “Sometimes you have to let the world know you’ve arrived.”

Jonah stifles a laugh. “Or that you’re compensating for something.”

The man’s smile never falters as he flips his keys in one hand. “You’d be surprised what people compensate for in this city.”

Jonah watches him stride toward the entrance of the old art deco building, curiosity piqued. He follows at a distance, noticing the hush that falls as the man enters the lobby. People part, eyes lingering on the impeccable suit and the confidence that radiates from every step.

Inside, the man turns back, catching Jonah’s gaze. “Did you want something?”

Jonah shrugs. “Just trying to figure out if you’re the kind of guy who buys a Ferrari, or the kind of guy who steals one.”

He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. The detectives exchanged glances, their faces impassive masks that betrayed nothing of the late-night hours spent poring over his statement. Outside, rain lashed the narrow windows of the interview room. The man—James—sat hunched, knuckles white where they gripped the edge of the metal table. 

"I only said what you wanted to hear," he insisted, voice cracking. "I was tired. Hungry. You wouldn’t let me see my lawyer."

Detective Ruiz leaned forward. "James, the evidence still points to you. The fingerprints, your car at the scene—"

"I know what it looks like!" James interrupted, desperate. "But I didn’t do it. Please, you have to believe me."

Ruiz studied him. The rain intensified, drumming a frenetic rhythm. Somewhere in the building, a phone rang. Ruiz wondered, not for the first time, if they’d gone too far. If truth was something you could force out of someone, or if it only came when you stopped demanding it. For now, all Ruiz could do was listen, and hope the storm outside would eventually clear.

Reggie looked downright petrified, while Hardy had now resorted to banging a catcher’s mitt–sized metal fist on the bulkhead. Hardy’s face, half flesh, half gleaming alloy, twisted in frustration. “You got a better idea?”

Reggie glanced at the cracked viewport. The swirling green clouds of Nebula 9 pressed close, and somewhere out in that storm, the derelict cruiser burned. “You said you had the access codes,” he whispered.

Hardy stopped banging, his mechanical hand flexing. “I do. But the pod’s locking system is fried. Only way out is brute force or...”

He trailed off. Reggie followed his gaze to the tiny maintenance hatch above them. “You’re not serious.”

Hardy grinned, teeth and titanium. “You fit. I boost you up, you crawl. It’s that or we wait for the oxygen to run out.”

Reggie gulped, then nodded. He’d never been claustrophobic before today.

After the sun slipped below the horizon and the last bus rumbled down the street, I’d sit on the stoop with a notebook balanced on my knee, letting the city’s hush settle over me. My neighbor, Mrs. Larkin, would sometimes shuffle past with her cat in tow, nodding in silent agreement that these were the only hours that truly belonged to us.

Tonight, though, the exhaustion is a living thing, heavy on my shoulders. But I promised myself I’d write the letter. Not for me, but for the memory of my brother, who left without a word ten years ago. The streetlights flicker overhead as I press pen to paper. “I hope you found what you were looking for,” I write, and wonder if the words will ever find him. Even if they don’t, I think, at least I tried. The effort, though small and late, is mine to keep. And as the night deepens, I realize I’m less tired than I thought.

), if I’m not too exhausted. That’s what I’d told myself as I stood at the edge of the old pier, looking out over the dark water. The moon was just a smudge behind clouds, and the town behind me was silent, save for the distant hum of a passing car. I tightened my grip on the envelope in my pocket—the one I’d been carrying for months, the one with no return address and just three words inside: “I remember you.”

I let the wind whip my hair, hoping it would blow away my hesitance. If I was too tired, I’d go home. But if not—if some last spark of courage remained—I’d drop the envelope into the river, let the current carry it wherever it needed to go. I took a breath, feeling the weight of exhaustion, the ache of old memories. Then I stepped forward, arm outstretched, and let go. The envelope sailed away, and for the first time in weeks, I felt a little lighter.

Somehow, in losing myself to those pages, I’d found a pocket of energy I didn’t know I had.

Reggie looked downright petrified, while Hardy had now resorted to banging a catcher’s mitt–sized metal fist on the bulkhead. The clang reverberated through the claustrophobic escape pod, a metallic heartbeat against their frantic breaths. “They’re getting closer,” Reggie whispered, eyes glued to the flickering sensor panel that pulsed with red warnings.

Hardy stopped pounding long enough to glance at Reggie. “We have to force the hatch. If we wait, it’ll be too late.”

“But the vacuum—”

“There’s a maintenance shaft. Trust me.”

Reggie’s hands trembled as Hardy wrenched open the access panel, exposing a tangle of wires and a narrow, dark tunnel. The pounding from outside grew louder—the boarding party was nearly through. Hardy shoved Reggie into the shaft first, then wedged his bulk in after. Crawling in the dark, Reggie’s fear mingled with a strange thrill. Could they really escape this way?

Behind them, the bulkhead finally gave way with a screech. Hardy grunted, pushing Reggie onward. "Don’t stop. Trust me."

As they disappeared into the shadows, the pod filled with angry voices. But Reggie clung to Hardy’s words, and crawled faster into the unknown.

Reggie looked downright petrified, while Hardy had now resorted to banging a catcher’s mitt–sized metal fist on the bulkhead. The shrill clang echoed through the submarine’s cramped corridor, masking the distant, telltale whine of something drilling through steel.

“Any luck?” Reggie’s voice quivered, his knuckles white as he gripped the emergency oxygen tank.

Hardy didn’t answer, just slammed his fist again, sending another metallic shudder down the length of the hull. Sweat dripped from his brow, pooling at the base of his jawline. “We’re running out of time, Reg. If the hull breaches—”

A low groan reverberated above their heads. Something heavy scraped across the deck.

“Is that—?”

“Don’t ask. Just get ready to move.” Hardy flexed the articulated fingers of his prosthetic hand, then lashed out at the bulkhead one last time. This time something gave—a seam split, just wide enough for him to wedge his body through.

Reggie hesitated only a moment. Then, with the eerie wail of metal all around, he followed Hardy into the darkness beyond the breach, hoping against hope that the next compartment would hold salvation rather than the sea.

Reggie looked downright petrified, while Hardy had now resorted to banging a catcher’s mitt–sized metal fist on the bulkhead. The clangs echoed through the cramped maintenance corridor, drowning out the distant, rhythmic hum of the reactor core. Shadows danced across Reggie’s face as emergency lights flickered, casting everything in an unsettling orange glow.

"You think they heard us?" Reggie’s words trembled, his eyes darting to the hatchway they’d sealed behind them.

Hardy didn’t pause, his voice gruff. "If they didn’t, we’re sunk anyway. This is the only way through."

Suddenly, the metal under Hardy’s fist buckled, a seam opening just enough for light to spill through. Hardy grinned, a wild glint in his eye. "Told you brute force sometimes works."

Reggie swallowed, inching forward. "Let’s hope it holds."

They scrambled through the opening, boots clanging on the floor. Behind them, the bulkhead rattled ominously, but for now, they were free—hurtling deeper into the labyrinthine ship, away from the unknown danger that stalked the corridors.

Hardy, unfazed, kept hammering, his mechanical arm whirring with each swing. “Better they come now than catch us crawling through the vent, Reg. Besides, I think—”

A concealed panel slid open with a hiss and a cascade of dust. Hardy grinned, wiped oil from his brow, and pried the hatch further with his fingertips. “There. Escape route.” He gestured for Reggie to climb in, the passage winding down into darkness.

Reggie hesitated, dread warring with relief. But as the first signs of pursuit echoed from the corridor behind them, he dove forward, Hardy close on his heels. In the belly of the ship, where even the lights seemed afraid, they disappeared into the unknown.

Are there children? The question echoed in the empty hallway of the abandoned station. Mara pressed her hand against the dusty wall, feeling for vibrations—any sign of life. The emergency beacon had been blinking for days, but no one answered her hails. She stepped forward, boots crunching on broken glass. Then, from a shadowed corner, a giggle. Mara froze. She called out, voice trembling, "Hello? Is anyone there?"

Another giggle, this time closer. From behind a toppled crate, a small hand waved. Mara’s heart leapt. She crouched, trying her best to sound gentle. "It’s okay. I’m here to help."

Two children peeked out, faces smudged, eyes wide with hope and fear. "Are you the rescue?" the older one asked.

Mara nodded. "Yes. Let’s get you somewhere safe."

As she led them away, the station’s lights flickered, and the children clung to her. Outside, the sky was beginning to glow with dawn. For the first time in days, Mara felt hope. There were children. And that meant there was still something left to save.

Are there children? That was the question they always asked first, standing at the edge of the garden, peering through the mist. This evening, only the faint forms of wild roses and tangled vines replied, their petals trembling in the breeze. But Sarah waited, as she had every night since the world changed, listening for laughter or the patter of quick feet.

She remembered a time when the yard overflowed with voices, games, and small, sticky hands clutching treasures. Now, only memories played among the shadows. Still, Sarah left the gate unlatched and a plate of bread and honey on the porch. Hope, she thought, is a muscle—one that grows stronger with use.

Tonight, just as she turned to go inside, a shape darted behind the old oak. Heart pounding, Sarah knelt and whispered softly, "Is someone there? Are you hungry?"

A child’s face appeared, cautious but curious. Behind her, another. Sarah smiled, tears in her eyes. The garden would bloom again. There were children after all.

He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. The detective, a veteran of two decades, sat across from him, arms folded. The young man’s hands trembled, voice hoarse from the previous night’s interrogation. “I didn’t do it,” he insisted. “You made me say those things. I was scared.”

In the small town of Rivington, news travels fast. By morning, the front page already bore his photo, the word ‘Confessed’ in bold. No one cared for the nuances; the story was simple, and they needed someone to blame. But the local librarian, Ms. Fletcher, wasn’t convinced. She’d watched the boy grow up between the stacks, always quiet and gentle.

She started her own investigation, poring over security footage and questioning regulars. Clues emerged: a missing library card, a witness who saw someone else near the back entrance. Ms. Fletcher brought her findings to the police, demanding they listen.

The detective, weary but not unkind, re-examined the evidence. This time, the truth was messy and inconvenient, but it mattered. The boy was released, but the damage lingered, a reminder that justice is often more fragile than anyone wants to admit.

He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. The words echoed through the austere police station, bouncing off linoleum and concrete, as Officer Harmon stared at the paperwork he’d spent all night filing. “That’s not what you said yesterday,” Harmon muttered, but the young man’s eyes were clearer now.

“I was scared. You said I’d never see my family again. You said things would be worse if I didn’t sign.”

Outside, the rain battered the windows, and the city seemed indifferent to the drama inside. Meanwhile, a public defender arrived, briefcase in hand, face pinched with exhaustion and determination. She listened quietly, then requested the interview tapes. As she watched, her frown deepened.

By the end of the week, the story had unraveled. The confession was thrown out, and a new investigation began—one led not by assumptions, but facts. The real culprit, emboldened by the chaos, made a mistake and was finally caught. But the young man remained wary, changed by the ordeal, his trust in justice forever tinged with doubt.

He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. The prosecutor stared at him across the table, frustration tightening her jaw. "You know what you said. The recording is clear."

"I only said it because they wouldn’t let me call my mother," he replied, voice shaking. "They said if I didn’t admit, they’d make sure I’d never get out."

As the days unfolded, the case began to unravel. Security footage surfaced, showing the real suspect, a shadowy figure slipping out the back door. Witnesses who’d been ignored came forward, insisting he’d been elsewhere that night. The town, which had been quick to judge, now murmured apologies in the grocery store aisle.

The officers who had pushed for a quick resolution found themselves under scrutiny. In the end, the truth emerged, but the damage was done. He walked free, but carried the weight of suspicion, and the knowledge that sometimes, fear speaks louder than the truth.

The lead detective avoided her gaze. The pressure to close the case had been immense, and they’d leaned hard—too hard. As the story unraveled, old secrets surfaced: similar complaints from the past, other confessions retracted. The department’s reputation began to crack.

In court, the young man stood tall, his voice steady as he described what really happened that night: the threats, the lies, the sense of hopelessness. The judge listened. The charges were dropped. He walked out into the sunlight, free but changed, knowing that justice, once bent, is slow to straighten.

Outside, activists staged midnight vigils, their candles burning through the fog. Among them stood his sister, holding a sign scrawled with his innocence. The evidence finally made its way to the judge, and the case unraveled like a poorly tied knot. He was freed, but the world he returned to was colder, trust fractured. The memory of those harsh lights and hard words lingered, a scar that would never quite fade.

He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. The room where they’d questioned him still floated in the back of his mind: too bright, the air stifling, and the detective’s eyes fixed on him with a predator’s patience. He remembered the trembling in his hands as he signed the paper, the unnatural calm that followed, and then the surge of regret that wouldn’t let him sleep. Now, under the gray light of morning, he faced the attorney assigned to his case. “I said what they wanted to hear," he whispered, voice hoarse. "They wouldn’t let me leave.”

The attorney took notes, pausing only to glance at the bruises on his wrists. “We’ll push for the video footage,” she said. “We’ll get you out.”

Outside, the city was waking up, indifferent to his turmoil. He wondered if the truth would survive another day, or if it would be drowned out by the voices of men who had already decided he was guilty. Either way, he had nothing left to lose.

instance_metrics.response:
He recanted his confession less than twenty-four hours later, saying it was coerced. No one believed him, not really. The officers smirked when he asked for a lawyer; the prosecutor shrugged, uninterested in his retraction. The confession was too tidy, too convenient—a perfect end to a messy case.

But in the sleepless hours after midnight, his mind replayed every detail: the harsh fluorescent lights, the metallic taste of fear, the detective’s relentless questions blurring into threats. He’d said what they wanted, desperate for a way out. Now, he was trapped by his own words.

His sister visited, pressing her hand to the glass. “I know you didn’t do it,” she whispered, though her eyes were rimmed red. “We’ll fight this.”

He nodded, but hope was a luxury. The system had a rhythm, and he'd stumbled into its crosshairs. Still, as the days passed, scraps of evidence surfaced. An alibi here, a surveillance tape there. Maybe, he thought, the truth could claw its way through after all.

She nodded, her pen scratching across a legal pad. “We’ll fight this,” she said simply. But as the days blurred into one another, he wondered if anyone would really care about his truth, or if the story had already been written for him.

“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man’s mirrored sunglasses catch the afternoon sun, scattering fragments of light onto the cracked sidewalk. He doesn’t smile, but there’s a twitch at the corner of his mouth—a secret amusement Jonah can’t quite read.

“Depends who’s looking,” the man replies, locking the car with a chirp that echoes down the quiet street.

Jonah leans against the lamppost, arms folded. “You must be here for the painting.”

The man nods, glancing at the shuttered windows above the pawn shop. “I heard you’re the one to talk to.”

Jonah studies him, searching for any sign of threat. The Ferrari suggested wealth, but wealth could be dangerous. Especially when it came to the kind of art people didn’t talk about in daylight.

“Follow me,” Jonah says, pushing off the lamppost. As they slip into the alley’s shadow, the city noise fades, replaced by the faint hum of anticipation. The man’s shoes make no sound on the asphalt—a detail that unsettles Jonah more than the car ever could.

“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man ignores him, straightening his pressed suit before glancing up and down the street. Even the pigeons seem to pause, uncertain whether to scatter.

Jonah waits, hands deep in his hoodie pocket. He’s not sure if this is the guy he’s supposed to meet, but the instructions were clear: ‘Wait by the bakery. Red Ferrari. Don’t look nervous.’

The man finally approaches, footsteps muffled by the thin layer of city dust. “You’re Jonah?”

Jonah nods. “You’re late.”

The man shrugs. “Traffic.”

Jonah almost laughs. “In that thing?”

“Especially in this thing,” the man replies, voice flat. “Let’s make this quick.”

They exchange a small, battered envelope. Neither man looks inside. Somewhere, a horn blares and a dog barks. The man returns to his Ferrari, sliding in with practiced ease.

Jonah watches the car melt into the city’s chaos, wondering what he’s just delivered—and to whom.

“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man glances over, unamused, and flicks an imaginary speck from his lapel. “It’s not about subtlety. It’s about making sure they know I’ve arrived.”

Jonah raises an eyebrow, suppressing a grin. The man’s shoes shine as much as the car, but it’s his eyes—sharp, calculating—that catch Jonah off guard.

“Are you the one with the information?” the man asks, voice barely above a whisper.

Jonah nods, shifting the envelope in his jacket pocket. He didn’t expect this much drama for a simple handoff, but then again, nothing was simple these days.

Without another word, the man extends a gloved hand. Jonah hesitates—just long enough to notice the man’s ring, a silver serpent coiled around his finger. He passes the envelope, hoping he won’t regret it.

The man smiles thinly, turns, and slides back into the Ferrari. Its engine purrs as he pulls away, leaving Jonah standing alone, heart pounding, in the echo of something bigger than he’d bargained for.

“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man flashes a toothy grin, running his hand along the car’s gleaming fender. “What can I say? I like to make an entrance.”

Jonah can’t help but smirk. The world around them seems to pause—a couple of teenagers stop mid-sentence, an old woman pretends to fumble with her groceries, but everyone is watching.

“You got what I asked for?” the man says, lowering his sunglasses and peering at Jonah as if he were a rare insect.

Jonah nods, pulling a small velvet pouch from his jacket. “Just like you wanted.”

The man takes it, weighing it in his palm. For a moment, something silent passes between them: suspicion, curiosity, maybe even respect.

“Pleasure doing business,” the man says, sliding back into the Ferrari. The engine roars to life, drowning out Jonah’s reply.

As the red streak disappears down the block, Jonah wonders if he’ll ever know what was really in that pouch—or if he even wants to.

Jonah chuckles, feeling the eyes of the café crowd pressed against them through the window. “You here for the audition, or just trying to give the pigeons a heart attack?”

The man grins, revealing a chipped tooth. “Both, maybe. Got the script?”

Jonah produces a dog-eared folder from his backpack and hands it over. The man rifles through the pages, lips moving silently. “You wrote the ending in code?”

“Wouldn’t want the wrong person to read it,” Jonah replies. 

The man nods, tucking the script under his arm. “I like your style, kid.”

He walks away without another word, leaving Jonah in the shadow of the Ferrari, wondering if he’d just cast the lead in his play—or started something far stranger.

instance_metrics.response: Yes, I was powerful. The kind of power that hummed beneath my skin, that made clocks shudder and the wind hesitate when I walked by. “Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari.

The man’s lips twitch in a half-smile. “I try not to draw attention,” he replies, smoothing the lapels of his midnight-blue suit. 

Jonah glances at the car’s gleaming red curves, the golden prancing horse badge, and the crowd that’s already gathering. He chuckles. “You succeed about as well as a peacock in a pigeon coop.”

The man laughs, but there’s a tension in his posture. He glances around, scanning the faces on the sidewalk, the windows above, the shadows between parked cars. Jonah notices, but pretends not to.

“Are you here for the auction?” Jonah asks, voice low.

The man nods, his eyes never still. “I hear there’s something special inside.”

Jonah follows his gaze to the warehouse doors. “Guess we’ll find out if it’s worth all this,” he says, and gestures toward the Ferrari, the attention, the risk.

The man grins, wolfish. “For some things, subtlety is overrated.”

Together, they step into the warehouse, the city’s noise falling away behind them.

Jonah leans against the lamppost, arms crossed. “Suppose it gets everyone else’s attention, too.”

The man smiles, revealing perfect teeth. “Sometimes, that’s the point.”

Jonah watches as the man shoulders a slim black briefcase and walks toward the nondescript building across the street. He wonders if the man knows he’s being watched, if he’s noticed the van parked two blocks down, or the woman with the newspaper who hasn’t turned a page in ten minutes.

“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man doesn’t glance his way, but Jonah notices the faintest smirk flicker across his lips. The city lights dance across the Ferrari’s hood, drawing attention from every passerby. The man flicks his keys into the air, catching them with practiced ease.

“You have an eye for understatement,” he responds, voice dry as dust. Jonah grins, shifting his backpack. He’s seen this man before—always in a rush, always driving something expensive. But tonight, the man seems to linger, surveying the sidewalk as if searching for something.

Jonah’s curiosity gets the better of him. “Waiting for someone?”

The man glances at him, eyes sharp. “Maybe I am. Maybe I’m here for a reason.”

A hush falls between them. The streetlights flicker. Then, suddenly, the man tosses Jonah the keys. “Park it for me, will you?” he says, vanishing into the night.

Jonah stares at the keys in his hand, heart pounding. Subtlety, he realizes, comes in many forms.

“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man pauses, runs a hand along the car’s crimson hood, and surveys the small, rain-soaked parking lot. He’s out of place here, all tailored lines and polished leather, while the rest of the world seems smudged and faded in comparison.

“Depends who’s looking,” he replies, voice smooth as the car’s finish. Jonah laughs quietly, watching the man lock the Ferrari with a chirp that echoes against the nearby laundromat.

Jonah’s curiosity gets the better of him. “You hiding from someone?”

The man raises an eyebrow, then gives a sly grin. “Aren’t we all?”

He disappears into the shadows, leaving Jonah staring after him, the scent of expensive cologne lingering in the air. When Jonah finally turns away, he notices a small envelope tucked beneath his windshield wiper. He opens it, and inside is a single key—and a challenge he can’t ignore.

The man offers a small, polite smile. “I prefer to travel incognito.”

Jonah chuckles, but the man’s gaze lingers on him a beat too long. There’s tension in the air, a sense of expectation. Jonah shifts on his feet, fingers brushing the envelope in his jacket pocket—the one marked with a symbol only a few would recognize.

The man walks towards him, footsteps crisp on the pavement. “Are you ready?” he asks quietly.

Jonah nods, pulse quickening. The night feels charged, the city suddenly full of possibilities. The Ferrari’s engine ticks as it cools, and somewhere inside, Jonah knows everything is about to change.

“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man pauses, glancing over his mirrored sunglasses with a look that says he’s heard the line before. He slides a violin case from the passenger seat, holding it with the care one might give to a sleeping child. The street is quiet, save for the ticking engine and the low hum of neon signs overhead.

“Sometimes,” the man replies, “the loudest thing in a room is what goes unsaid.”

Jonah watches, curiosity piqued. The man strides past, shoes clicking on the pavement, and heads for the alley’s narrow mouth. Something about the scene feels off—a violin in this part of town, at this hour? Jonah follows, drawn by the oddity. As he rounds the corner, he sees the man kneel beside a battered stray cat, opening the case not to reveal an instrument, but cans of food, each meticulously labeled.

“Subtle,” Jonah whispers, grinning, as the Ferrari’s brashness fades into the night’s quiet kindness.

instance_metrics.response: He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. The night air was thick with the scent of overturned earth, and his lantern cast wild shadows across the crumbling gravestones. With trembling hands, he pulled the bundle free, its weight unfamiliar and oddly warm. When he unwrapped the cloth, moonlight caught the delicate filigree of brass and the intricate teeth of the gears. A clockwork heart, just as the letter had described. He turned it over, searching for the inscription hidden on its underside: "For her return. Wind at midnight." His breath caught. Was it truly possible? The legend claimed the heart could bring back what was lost, but only if one dared to offer something precious in exchange. He glanced at the photograph tucked in his breast pocket—a face smiling, long gone. The gears in his hand shimmered, and somewhere in the darkness, a whisper urged him on. He knelt, the dirt cold beneath his knees, and wound the heart, the ticking echoing in the silence. As the final click sounded, the wind shifted, and he knew the bargain had begun.

His hands shook as he wound the key, the gears inside creaking with age. As the first note played, a pale blue light shimmered across the stone walls of the alley. Shadows danced and memories flickered at the edge of his vision. He closed his eyes, letting the melody carry him back to the moment he’d lost her, hoping for a chance to change everything. When he opened them again, the song was ending. He was no longer alone.
