I pace in front of the TV, feeling a jittery excitement. It’s only a show, but it’s the finale, and we’ve been waiting for months. The bathroom door clicks shut, muffling the sounds of zippers and giggling. I glance back at the screen—buffering, of course. I tap my foot, willing the Wi-Fi to cooperate. 

From inside the bathroom, there’s a faint humming, then a thud, like a dropped shampoo bottle. I call out, “Everything okay in there?”

“Yeah! Just… give me a sec!”

I smirk. Probably another wardrobe malfunction. The episode finally loads, the title card glowing on the screen. I hover my thumb over play. The door opens, and she emerges—wearing my old college hoodie, eyes shining with anticipation. 

“Ready?” she asks, plopping next to me. I nod, but something feels different—like the night is more than just a season finale. Maybe it’s the way she leans in, or the way her hand finds mine. We press play, the opening theme rising. In that moment, for reasons I don’t yet understand, it feels like the start of something bigger than both of us.

The TV flickers to life, casting a blue glow across the living room. I scroll through rows of thumbnails, nerves jangling for no reason I can name. In the bathroom, I hear her humming, the metallic click of a belt, the rustle of fabric. It’s a little domestic ballet we’ve perfected—she changes, I cue up our favorite show. 

I finally find the episode, but as I hover over the play button, the power flickers. The TV goes black. My heart jumps. Silence. Then, from the bathroom: “Did the lights just go out?”

“Yeah,” I say, voice shaky. “Looks like the whole block.”

She opens the door, mascara half-applied, pajamas dangling from her hand. We stand together in the quiet, then burst into laughter. The city’s dark but our apartment feels warm. I light a candle, she tosses me a blanket, and we sit cross-legged on the floor, telling each other stories until the power returns. The show can wait. Some nights, the best episodes aren’t on TV at all.

Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said. The tension in the room thickened, the kind that made your ears ring and your skin itch. Across from him, Lina’s jaw tensed. “Mari wouldn’t lie about something like this. You know it.”

Gabe shrugged, picking at the edge of the coffee table. “I know what I know, Lina. And what I know is that the necklace was missing, and Mari was the last one in the room.”

A door creaked upstairs, and their voices dropped to a hush. Lina leaned in. “You’re letting suspicion blind you. Mari’s family to us.”

Gabe’s gaze hardened, haunted by the memory of trust broken before. “Sometimes, it’s the ones closest to us.”

The silence crackled. Upstairs, a footstep. Downstairs, trust eroded further, until nothing but doubt remained.

Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said. The accusation hung in the air, heavy and electric. Cora’s eyes burned into his, unblinking. “You saw the bruises, Gabe. She didn’t just fall.”

He shifted in his chair, uncomfortable. “People get hurt all the time. Accidents happen.”

Cora shook her head. “Mari doesn’t make up things. Especially not about him.”

Gabe’s hands curled into fists. He wanted to believe Mari, wanted to believe Cora, but the truth was a slippery thing, always just out of reach. He thought about the nights Mari came home late, her voice small, her stories inconsistent. He thought about the way she flinched when anyone raised their voice.

He looked at Cora, searching for certainty and finding only fear. “Then we need to help her,” he said quietly.

Cora nodded, relief trembling at the corners of her mouth. “Together, then.”

Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said. The words tasted bitter, even as he said them. Across the counter, Felix’s hands tightened into fists. “She told me she saw you at the docks last night. Said you were talking to strangers.”

Gabe looked away, the flicker of guilt passing over his face. “A lot of people go to the docks. Maybe she got confused.”

Felix shook his head. “Mari doesn’t get confused. Not about this. Who were you meeting?”

Gabe’s silence stretched, heavy and accusing. Outside, a storm was gathering—the kind that promised to break things apart. Finally, Gabe spoke, voice low. “I can’t tell you. Not yet.”

Felix’s eyes narrowed. “Then I have no reason to trust either of you.”

The distance between them grew, impossible and wide, as thunder rumbled in the distance.

instance_metrics.response: Yes, I was powerful. Once, my words bent the will of kings and my gestures summoned tempests from clear skies. But power, I've learned, is a fickle guest. Children come to listen to my stories, their eyes round with wonder, and I see in them the same spark I once carried. Perhaps true power isn't in command or conquest, but in the stories we leave behind, echoing long after our voices fade.

Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said, his voice quiet but unflinching. The words hung in the air longer than they should have, echoing off the faded wallpaper and mixing with the faint scent of lavender from the old armchair. Across from him, Lena’s face hardened, her fingers clenching the mug of tea so tightly Gabe worried it might shatter.

“You don’t know her,” Lena whispered. “You don’t know what she’s been through.”

Gabe shrugged, feigning indifference. “Everyone’s been through something. Doesn’t mean they’re always honest about it.”

A storm rumbled outside, and Lena’s eyes darted to the window. “If you accuse her, you accuse me. We’re the same.”

Gabe’s gaze softened for a moment, but only for a moment. “Then prove it. Tell me what really happened that night.”

Lena’s jaw set, and in the silence, Gabe realized the truth was something neither of them wanted to say aloud. Sometimes, stories were easier to believe than the reality they hid.

Reggie looked downright petrified, while Hardy had now resorted to banging a catcher’s mitt–sized metal fist on the bulkhead. The echoing clangs reverberated down the cramped corridor of the derelict mining ship, stirring up a fine haze of dust. "Will you stop?" Reggie hissed, clutching the emergency beacon like a talisman. "If something's in here with us--"

"Then it already knows," Hardy grunted, his synthetic voice box making the words sound like gravel poured over sheet metal. Sweat trickled down Reggie's temple. He could still hear the skittering in the vents above, sometimes close, sometimes distant. "How long until the rescue team gets here?"

"Longer than you want," Hardy replied, peering through a cracked viewport into the engine room. The lights flickered. The skittering stopped. They both froze. A shadow, long and impossibly thin, slid across the far wall. Reggie stifled a whimper. Hardy raised his metal fist again, but this time not at the bulkhead—he aimed it at whatever was coming. "Stay close," he said. "And if I say run, you run."

Hardy’s LED eyes flickered blue, the universal sign for exasperation. "If it wanted us, we’d be dead already. Help me with the override."

But Reggie’s legs wouldn’t move. His mind replayed the moment the lights went out, the scraping sound in the ductwork. Whatever was on this derelict freighter didn’t want simply to be found. It wanted to hunt.

But the hours ticked by, and the search party’s voices faded behind the trees. Maybe she was lost, or maybe she was hiding. I clung to the idea that there was a plan, that someone somewhere was piecing together the clues I’d missed. Still, doubt gnawed at the edges of my hope. What if no one cared as much as I did? What if the world moved on, and I was the only one left searching? I pressed my ear to the quiet, listening for her footsteps, willing myself to believe that, somewhere, help was on the way.

The silence stretched, taut as wire.

Then, a scraping noise, soft but unmistakable, as if someone were dragging their nails across the floorboards. She backed away, heart pounding, every muscle coiled for flight. "Show yourself," she whispered, voice trembling, hoping the tremor would be masked by bravado. The darkness seemed to lean closer, listening, waiting. Then, from the blackness, a low, familiar voice: "You shouldn’t have come back."

“Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said, voice steady but his eyes flickering to the rain streaking the window. The silence that followed was thick, broken only by the hum of the old refrigerator. Lydia crossed her arms, knuckles white. “You’re just going to take her word for it? After everything?”

Gabe’s jaw tightened. “She’s never lied to me before.”

“That you know of,” Lydia shot back. She picked up the faded photograph from the table—the one with all three of them smiling in the sunlight last summer, before the secrets, before the missing money.

“If you really trust her, then ask her where she was last night,” Lydia whispered. “Ask her to her face.”

Gabe hesitated. Through the window, Mari’s silhouette paused at the gate, umbrella tipped against the wind. He watched as she approached, heart pounding. The truth—or the lie—was seconds away from stepping through the door.

Tomorrow, she’d return at dawn, when the mist curled low and secrets seemed closest to surfacing. Maybe then, she’d prove she wasn’t just imagining things.

A shadow flickered near the fence. "Hello?" she called. Silence. Then, a whisper: "Are there children?" It wasn't her voice. She turned, and a dozen eyes blinked open in the darkness, glimmering like dew on spiderwebs. The laughter started again, soft and sad. Mrs. Bell backed away slowly, but the question followed her, echoing through the empty rooms, night after night.

Reggie looked downright petrified, while Hardy had now resorted to banging a catcher’s mitt–sized metal fist on the bulkhead. The sub lurched. Hardy braced himself against the wall, glowering at the viewport, where a shadow flickered. “We’re not alone down here.”

As if on cue, the emergency lights snapped off. In the darkness, a dull glow shimmered from the viewport—a phosphorescent mass undulating just inches from the glass. Reggie whimpered. Hardy’s fist slammed the bulkhead again, this time in a desperate rhythm, as if to ward off the deep’s encroaching terror.

Suddenly, a garbled voice crackled through the comms, “Surface to Deep Six… do you copy?”

Reggie’s fear gave way to frantic hope. “Yes! We’re here!”

Hardy grunted, each blow a futile attempt to summon help from above. “They can’t hear us. Or worse—they can and don’t care.”

A strange vibration thrummed underfoot. The lights flickered, and something outside the porthole pressed close—something with too many eyes, watching. Reggie squeezed his eyes shut. “This isn’t happening. We’re not supposed to be this deep.”

Hardy paused, staring at the thing outside, then at Reggie. “You ever wonder what it’s like to be on the other side of the glass?”

Reggie shook his head, shivering. As the bulkhead groaned and the timer neared zero, Hardy’s fist stilled. “Either we wait and hope, or we find our own way out.”

The thing outside smiled.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

Mara’s voice was barely a whisper as she watched the yellow moonlight glimmer on the water’s surface. She remembered the stories—of currents that pulled, of shadows that watched from beneath. But this was the lake, not the river, and she wanted to believe it was different.

Tom stood behind her, arms crossed, shivering in the early autumn chill. “I still don’t get it. Why here? Why tonight?”

She pressed the old silver key into his palm. “It’s the only place I can try. The lake remembers.”

He glanced at the black water, uncertain. “And if it doesn’t?”

Mara shrugged, a small, sad smile. “Then the secret stays lost.”

She waded in, the cold biting at her ankles and knees, until the water lapped at her waist. She whispered words she’d never said aloud, words her grandmother taught her long ago. The lake listened. The wind stilled. And, for just a moment, something beneath the surface glowed—a slow, gentle light—before fading away.

Mara turned, hope flickering in her eyes. “Maybe it’s not lost after all.”

Arjun squinted, trying to catch the glint of mischief in Lila’s eyes. She was already halfway down the old wooden pier, barefoot, her sundress fluttering behind her in the late summer breeze.

"You’re serious?" he called out, shuffling awkwardly, sneakers crunching on gravel. He’d heard the stories—about the snapping turtles and the ancient carp lurking in the mud, not to mention the legend of Old Man Brack, who vanished one night under a thunderstorm.

Lila grinned, dipping her toes in. "Come on, it’s just water."

He hesitated, but her laughter was infectious. The lake rippled, reflecting pink streaks of dusk. Arjun took a breath, threw off his shoes, and ran after her, the boards creaking beneath him.

When they plunged in, the water was shockingly cold, but alive. They dove under, resurfacing with wild gasps and delighted shouts. For a moment, the lake held just the two of them—no ghosts, no legends, just the thrill of doing something a little bit reckless on a fading summer night.

All I wanted was to have her back.” Silence engulfs us for a long time before Mr. Lamont speaks again. His voice is brittle, as though each word is a stone dropped into an endless well. “I used to believe I could bargain with fate,” he says. “That if I tried hard enough, searched deep enough, I’d find the right words, the right magic to undo what’s been done.”

Rain taps the windowpane in a slow, relentless rhythm. I glance at the photograph on the mantel, its edges curled, the colors faded to sepia. Her smile is a ghost there, lingering just beyond my reach.

Mr. Lamont continues, “But the world doesn’t work that way. There are places and people we can’t return to. I’m learning that now.” He stands, his cane trembling in his grip. “Still, some mornings I wake up and for a split second, I hear her laughter. That’s what keeps me going.”

He shuffles to the door, pausing before he leaves. “If you ever figure out how to bring someone back, let me know.”

The door clicks shut, leaving only the echo of memory and the hush of rain.

All I wanted was to have her back.” Silence engulfs us for a long time before Mr. Lamont speaks again. He clears his throat, but the words seem stuck somewhere deep inside him. Finally, he exhales a shaky breath. “You know,” he says, “I used to think there was a way. Some secret thread I could unravel, some bargain I could strike.”

The room is heavy with the scent of old books and the faint ticking of a battered clock. I want to reassure him, to say that time heals, but the words feel hollow.

“I kept her letters,” Mr. Lamont says suddenly, his gaze fixed on the yellowed envelope in his hand. “Each one, a piece of her I could keep safe. But paper wears thin, and ink fades.” He presses the letter to his chest, as if he could conjure her back through sheer longing.

Outside, thunder rumbles. “Maybe we don’t ever get them back,” he whispers. “We just learn to carry the empty spaces.”

He closes his eyes, letting the silence return, heavier than before.

All I wanted was to have her back.” Silence engulfs us for a long time before Mr. Lamont speaks again. The lamp flickers, casting strange shadows across the wallpaper. He finally lifts his gaze, his eyes gleaming with something like defiance. “You think I haven’t tried?” he asks, voice trembling. “I went to the river every night, whispering her name. I left offerings, begged the wind, even followed the old rituals my grandmother spoke of.”

He laughs, a brittle sound. “But she never came. Not as a ghost, not as a dream. Only memories, and those are crueler than any haunting.”

I shift in my chair, uncertain how to comfort him. The air is thick with longing, too dense to breathe. Mr. Lamont stands, his shadow stretching toward me. “Grief is a door, but it only opens one way.”

He walks away, leaving me alone with the silence he carried in.

All I wanted was to have her back.” Silence engulfs us for a long time before Mr. Lamont speaks again. When he does, it’s almost a whisper, a secret meant only for the dust motes dancing in the slanting afternoon sun. “I see her sometimes, you know,” he says, not looking at me. “Not really, but… in the corner of my eye, or in the way the curtains move. Like she’s just stepped out of the room.”

His hands twist in his lap, restless. “Maybe I’m losing my mind. Maybe that’s the price for loving someone so much.”

He smiles, but it’s a fragile thing, gone as quickly as it appeared. “If I could just speak to her once more, hear her scold me for leaving my shoes in the hallway… But all I have is this silence, and it doesn’t answer back.”

Outside, the wind rattles the window, and I realize I don’t know what to say. Some silences are too deep to fill.

His voice, when it comes, is softer than before, weighed down with years that seem to settle on his shoulders all at once. “It’s strange, isn’t it?” he murmurs. “How absence becomes a presence in itself. How a person’s favorite mug, the dent in a pillow, the way the door creaks at midnight—they all become reminders, like ghosts haunting the living.”

He runs a trembling hand over the frayed arm of his chair. “I planted her favorite lilies by the window last spring. They bloomed fiercely, like they were trying to make up for her not being here to tend them. I’d talk to them sometimes, just to fill the silence.”

He looks up, meeting my eyes for the first time. There’s a flicker of hope mixed with sorrow. “Maybe she’s not gone, not really. Maybe she’s in those lilies, in the sunlight, in the spaces she left behind.”

The silence returns, but now it feels gentler, full of memories that neither of us dare disturb.

She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The room was thick with the scent of ozone and scorched wood; the storm outside had broken a window, and rain was pooling on the warped floorboards. She crouched behind a battered armchair, heart pounding. The silhouette by the window shifted, a subtle scrape of boot against glass. “I know you’re there,” she called, voice shaking but loud. No answer. Only the wind, howling through the jagged hole. 

She reached for the fireplace poker, her hand closing around cold iron. She’d seen the fall, the flash of his coat as he tumbled from the attic, but she couldn’t believe he was gone. He was always two steps ahead, always the one to find her first. Thunder cracked overhead. A shadow flickered. She tightened her grip and waited, determined not to let fear swallow her whole. Tonight, she promised herself, she would not run.

She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The air was heavy, each breath tasting of old dust and something metallic. She edged along the wall, fingers trailing over peeling wallpaper, the only barrier between her and the memory of his voice. 

A low groan sounded from the other side of the overturned table. She swallowed hard, summoning the courage to peer through a gap in the furniture. He was sprawled on the ground, face turned away, a crimson stain blooming across his sleeve. But his hand twitched, fingers curling and uncurling with intent. 

She backed away, bumping into the sideboard. A glass figurine wobbled, threatened to fall. "Stay back," she whispered, mostly to herself. The room, once familiar, now felt alien—corners too dark, shadows too deep. She wondered if she could make it to the door before he rose, or if she’d have to confront the secrets she’d spent so long trying to bury.

She edged backward, the legs of the chair scraping in protest. The silence that followed was almost worse than the crash. She could see the outline of his boot, motionless—at least for now. Her mind raced: had he seen her? Did he even know she was still here? She glanced around for anything she could use—an umbrella, a heavy lamp, anything to tip the scales. 

He shifted suddenly. She froze, every muscle taut. The next move would decide everything, and she had to make it count. She braced herself, ready to do whatever it took to survive the night.

He looked puzzled, wrong-footed entirely. The chessboard in front of him was a battlefield, and his opponent—a wiry woman with a mischievous grin—had just executed a move he didn’t see coming. For weeks, he’d practiced, studied gambits and counterattacks, but now he was staring at a checkmate in three, unable to fathom how he’d landed in such a trap.

Outside, the rain rattled against the window of the old café. Inside, a small crowd had gathered, watching the match unfold. His hands trembled as he reached for his queen, only to realize any move spelled disaster. His opponent leaned back, folding her arms, radiating patience and triumph in equal measure.

Desperate, he glanced up at her. "Is there any way out?"

She chuckled softly. "Sometimes the best move is to know when you’re beaten."

With a sheepish smile, he toppled his king. The crowd erupted in applause. Despite his defeat, he felt a strange sense of relief. Losing, he realized, could sometimes teach more than winning ever could.

He looked puzzled, wrong-footed entirely. The map in his hands trembled as he squinted at the faded lines, trying to reconcile the path he’d taken with the reality before him. The woods were supposed to end at a meadow, but instead, an ancient stone wall blocked his way, thick with moss and crawling ivy.

He pressed his palm to the cold stone, half-expecting it to crumble, but it held fast. Behind him, the wind whispered, carrying faint laughter. Turning, he saw only the shifting shadows of trees, nothing more. Yet the sense of being watched prickled along his skin.

Swallowing, he circled the wall, searching for a gate or a breach. The map offered no clue, just a smudge where the wall now stood. He hesitated, then followed the wall’s curve until he reached a small archway, hidden by brambles. Heart pounding, he ducked through, drawn by curiosity more than courage.

On the other side, the world was different—quiet, sunlit, filled with wildflowers and the flutter of unseen wings. He took a breath, trusting that sometimes the wrong path led to the right place.

He looked puzzled, wrong-footed entirely. The page was blank, but the professor's eyes burned with expectation. He glanced at his classmates, but they were already scribbling furiously. Had he missed something? Was there a question he’d overlooked, or was this some kind of test?

His pen hovered over the paper, heart pounding. Time ticked by, and the silence grew heavier. He tried to recall the professor’s instructions, but his mind spun in circles. Write what you know, she’d said. Or was it, write what you fear?

In a burst of desperation, he began to write about his confusion, about the pressure of a blank page and the fear of failing. The words spilled out, messy but honest. When the bell rang, he handed in his paper with a trembling hand.

Days later, he was called to the professor’s office. She handed back his paper with a smile. "Sometimes," she said, "the truest stories begin with uncertainty."

He looked puzzled, wrong-footed entirely. The dog at his feet barked twice and trotted down the hallway, as if expecting him to follow. With a hesitant shrug, he obeyed, passing family photos he didn’t recognize and furniture that felt both familiar and foreign.

He had no memory of how he’d come to this house, or why the faint smell of cinnamon bread baking made him uneasy. The dog waited patiently by a closed door. Taking a deep breath, he turned the knob.

Inside, a little girl sat cross-legged on the rug, crayon in hand, drawing a picture of a man and a dog. She looked up and smiled. "You’re home now," she said softly.

He knelt beside her, questions swirling, but the warmth in her eyes eased his confusion. The dog curled up beside them, and for the first time in a long while, he felt a hesitant hope that maybe he belonged somewhere after all.

Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said, but his eyes flicked to the side, betraying a hint of doubt. The sun had long dipped below the field’s edge, and shadows stretched between the rows of corn behind them.

Kat crossed her arms. “She’s never lied to us before. Why would she start now?”

Gabe scuffed his shoe along the gravel. “People change.”

Kat shook her head, voice low. “Not Mari. Not about something like this.”

“In the swimming lake.”

Mara’s voice was thin, stretched by the humid night air. She was sitting on the old dock, feet dangling above the water. The moon shimmered on the lake’s surface, hiding the secrets beneath.

“I saw it,” she whispered. “A shape, like a shadow, but moving against the current.”

Dylan knelt beside her, squinting into the darkness. “You sure it wasn’t just a fish? Or the old tire?”

Mara shook her head. “It was watching. I could feel it.”

For a while, neither spoke. The distant hum of cars from the highway faded, leaving only the gentle lap of water. Then something rippled—just beyond the reach of their toes.

Dylan stood, suddenly uneasy. “Let’s go back. Grandpa says the lake keeps what it takes.”

Mara lingered, staring at the black water, heart thumping. When she finally rose to leave, a cold splash hit her ankle. She gasped, spinning, but there was nothing—just the lake, dark and endless, waiting for the next secret to swallow.

They left the dock behind, but Mara felt the lake’s eyes lingering, patient and silent beneath the moon.

They watched the sun slip away, shadows growing long, and wondered what the water would reveal at dawn.

The room seemed to shrink around them as Gabe spoke. Sunlight filtered through the dusty blinds, striping the old hardwood floor in pale gold. Across from him, Lena’s jaw tightened. “She was the only one in the library that night. The only one who could have seen it.”

Gabe shrugged, feigning nonchalance, but his eyes flicked toward the closed door. “Mari doesn’t have any reason to make up stories. She’s not like that.”

Lena’s gaze softened, just a little. “You trust her, don’t you?”

He hesitated. “I trust that she saw something. But whether it was what she thinks… that’s different.”

The silence pressed in. Lena toyed with the frayed edge of her sleeve. “If she’s wrong, Gabe, it could ruin everything.”

A floorboard creaked in the hallway. Both of them looked up, startled. Mari stood there, hands clenched at her sides, eyes wide. “I know what I saw,” she whispered. “And I can prove it.”

Gabe swallowed. Suddenly, the truth seemed far more dangerous than any lie.

These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. Lined neatly across her faded quilt, they watched the world with gleaming button eyes, silent witnesses to her whispered secrets and sleepless midnight tears. As the years passed, she’d given each a name, a distinct personality, and a place in her heart’s theater. Giraffey was the brave explorer. Miss Buttons, the wise counselor. Frodo the bear, a quiet companion who listened without judgment.

She remembered the first time she’d realized their affection was a one-way street—a birthday party where the other children laughed at her for bringing along Marshmallow, her limp, beloved rabbit. The sting of embarrassment was sharp, but at night, Marshmallow was still soft and warm in her arms. Love, she realized, was not always about reciprocity. Sometimes it was about giving, about being steadfast even when you knew nothing would come back. Years later, as she boxed up the animals for storage, she pressed a kiss to Marshmallow’s threadbare forehead. "Thank you," she whispered. She was ready to love the world, even if it didn’t always love her back.

These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. As a child, she’d arranged them by size and color on her bed, making sure none felt left out. At night, she rotated who slept closest to her pillow so everyone had a turn. She whispered apologies into their stitched ears after accidental drops, convinced her affection could fix their loose seams or faded patches.

Years later, she caught herself treating people the same way—careful not to favor one friend over another, offering patience and apologies for things beyond her control. But love, she learned, could be met with silence or, sometimes, indifference. Unlike her stuffed animals, people didn’t always stay when you needed them most. Still, she persisted, believing in the quiet strength of loving without guarantee. When she moved out of her childhood home, she tucked her favorite bear into a suitcase. Its one remaining button eye glinted in the afternoon sun, a small reminder that love’s true lesson is endurance—not expectation.

These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. Each one carried a story, stitched into their seams by her tiny hands and wild imagination. No matter how tightly she hugged the faded elephant or how many adventures she invented for the patchwork fox, their glass eyes never blinked in gratitude. Yet, she kept loving them fiercely, mending their tears and dusting off their fur, refusing to let go.

Years later, when her mother grew ill, the lesson returned. She found herself in that hospital room, holding her mother’s hand, offering stories and comfort, knowing that the love she poured out might not be returned in the way she yearned for. But she understood now: some kinds of love are measured not by what comes back, but by what you give. As the machines hummed and her mother slept, she found peace in this old, quiet truth—love, in its purest form, asks for nothing but itself.

But every time she straightened a drooping flower or picked up a threadbare bear, she remembered: love could be an offering, a quiet promise you kept for yourself, even when no one was listening.

She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The room was slick with shadows, the only illumination a trembling line of moonlight slicing across the floorboards. She steadied her breath, fingers curled tight around the cool wooden back of a chair. He hadn’t made another sound—no creak, no scrape, not even the hush of drawn breath. Yet she felt his presence, thick and electric, pressing into the silence. 

Her mind raced, retracing the last few minutes: the window banging open, the thud on the rug, the voice that wasn’t quite human. Now he was somewhere beyond the dining table, obscured by tall-backed chairs and the shuddering dark. She weighed her options, heart hammering. Run? Scream? Or wait, poised and listening, for him to reveal himself? 

Something shifted, a glint catching her eye. A hand, pale and impossibly long, closed around the chair opposite her. She swallowed a cry. The moonlight caught on his teeth as he smiled, a slow, deliberate movement. "You always did like to play hide-and-seek," he whispered.

She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. For a moment, silence pressed against her eardrums, so thick she thought she might burst. Then, a faint scuff—a shoe against tile?—and she tightened her grip on the nearest chairback, knuckles whitening. The kitchen clock ticked on, oblivious. 

She scanned for anything she could use—a fork, a vase, the heavy candlestick on the sideboard. Her mind flickered to the phone, left charging in the hallway, too far to reach. He was closer now. She could sense it, the way you sense a thunderstorm rolling in, the way the air changes.

"You don’t have to be afraid," he said. His voice sounded wrong, stretched at the edges, as if borrowed from someone else. She did not answer. Instead, she inched sideways, keeping the chairs between them, her breath trembling in her chest. She wondered if he could hear it—the way prey’s heartbeat betrays it to the hunter.

A whisper—barely audible—brushed her ear. "Come closer." She froze, every muscle taut. The voice was familiar, but not quite right, as though it echoed from a memory she couldn’t place. The chairs were her only barrier now, a fragile line of defense. She weighed her options, eyes never leaving the darkness, waiting for a shape to emerge.

He looked puzzled, wrong-footed entirely. The chessboard between them seemed to mock his confusion, the black bishop glinting in the lamplight. For years, he’d played his father every Thursday evening, but never had he faced such a strange opening. The old man’s lips curled in a knowing smile. “You’re thinking too much about the past, Theo,” he said. “Try to see what’s in front of you.”

Theo hesitated, his hand hovering over the knight. Move after move, his father’s strategy unfolded in patterns Theo couldn’t recognize. He realized, with a start, that he was no longer playing against the father he’d always known, but against someone who had grown, changed, become mysterious in his old age.

Finally, with a sigh, Theo tipped his king. His father’s eyes softened. “It’s not always about winning,” he said, reaching to reset the pieces. “Sometimes it’s about seeing the game in a new light.”

Theo smiled, feeling the weight of old expectations lift. Maybe, he thought, losing wasn’t so bad after all.

He looked puzzled, wrong-footed entirely. The elevator doors had opened onto a hallway he’d never seen before, lined with mirrors that reflected his bewilderment in endless repetition. He stepped forward, the doors hissing shut behind him, and his footsteps echoed unnaturally loud. Each mirror seemed to ripple as he passed, distorting his image—taller, shorter, older, younger.

At the end of the hall, a door stood slightly ajar. Light spilled out, warm and golden, and inside, he could hear laughter—his own, but from years ago. He hesitated, fingers brushing the doorframe. Was this a memory, or something else entirely?

Inside, he saw himself as a child, building a castle out of blocks, his mother watching fondly. He watched for a long moment, heart aching with nostalgia and confusion. Then the laughter faded, and the light dimmed. The boy looked up, as if he could see him, and smiled.

He turned away, finding his reflection steadier now. He wasn’t lost, just somewhere new. Maybe, he thought, every strange hallway led to a piece of himself he’d forgotten.

“Urueta is going to give you the interview you need sooner or later.”

“He doesn’t like us.”

“He got a little tense, but Urueta loves talking.”

The two journalists huddled by the cracked window, watching the rain slide down the glass. Across the street, Urueta’s neon-lit café glowed like a beacon in the dusk. Inside, the man himself paced between the tables, gesturing animatedly to no one in particular. 

“Look, he’s rehearsing,” whispered Lena.

“Or arguing with ghosts,” muttered Paulo.

They waited. Their notebooks balanced on their knees, tape recorder ready. The café’s door finally swung open with a metallic groan. Urueta stepped out, umbrella forgotten, hair wild. He stared at them, suspicion flickering in his eyes.

“Are you going to keep lurking, or order a coffee?”

Lena smiled, hopeful. “We’d love to talk.”

Urueta sighed, but the corner of his mouth twitched. “You’re relentless. Fine. But only if you try my chocolate cake. It’s my grandmother’s recipe.”

As the rain softened, the three of them disappeared inside, the promise of stories—and cake—hanging sweetly in the air.

“Urueta is going to give you the interview you need sooner or later.”

“He doesn’t like us.”

“He got a little tense, but Urueta loves talking.”

The newsroom’s flickering fluorescent lights cast a pallor over my editor’s face. I watched as he tapped a pen against his mug, coffee long gone cold. 

“Just be patient,” he said. “He’s stubborn, but he loves the attention.”

I nodded, but doubt gnawed at me. My last attempt had ended with Urueta slamming his door in my face and muttering about ‘vultures’. Still, I couldn’t stop thinking about the rumors swirling around him: the hidden manuscripts, the midnight meetings, the old map nailed to his study wall.

The phone rang. I nearly jumped. My editor answered, listened, then thrust the receiver toward me.

“It’s him,” he mouthed.

I grabbed the phone. Urueta’s voice crackled with static and impatience. “If you want the story, meet me at the pier. Midnight.”

The line went dead. My heart hammered. Finally, the story was within reach—if I was brave enough to follow him into the shadows.

“Urueta is going to give you the interview you need sooner or later.”

“He doesn’t like us.”

“He got a little tense, but Urueta loves talking.”

I glance at my phone, thumb hovering over the call button. The recording device on my desk feels heavier than it should. I remember the last time I saw Urueta—his eyes darted like a trapped animal’s, but his words spilled out in a torrent once he started. Maybe he just needed the right question, or maybe he just liked the sound of his own voice more than he disliked journalists like me.

I finally dial his number. It rings once, twice, then a gruff voice answers.

“Urueta,” he barks. I can hear the clatter of dishes in the background.

“This is Mara from the Chronicle. I was hoping to—”

He interrupts, “You want the truth or the headlines?”

“Both, if you’ll let me.”

A pause. Then, a sigh. “Come by after nine. Bring questions, not assumptions.”

I hang up, relieved. The interview is on. I just hope I’m ready for the answers.

But in the weeks since the scandal broke, Urueta had become a ghost in the city, leaving only whispers and rumors in his wake. Still, my editor insisted he’d come around. I found myself every morning passing the old bakery where he used to hold impromptu press conferences, hoping for a sign.

“Urueta is going to give you the interview you need sooner or later.”

“He doesn’t like us.”

I pressed my ear against the thin wall separating his cluttered office from the dimly-lit hallway, catching fragments of his one-sided conversations with the shadows. He looked up, suspicion flickering, then recognition dawning.

I nodded, pen poised. He waved me closer, lowering his voice. “Then you’d better be ready for what comes after. Some stories can’t stay in the dark forever.”

As the ancient radiator hummed and dusk pressed against the window, Urueta leaned in, ready to talk—and I realized I’d stepped into a tale far deeper than I’d imagined.

These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. She lined them up on the end of her bed every night, tucking the bear's frayed paw under the unicorn’s soft mane, arranging them in the precise order she’d decided was right. The rabbit, missing an eye, always got the place closest to her pillow. She whispered into its worn fur her tiny secrets and the names of classmates she hoped would like her. 

As she grew, the stuffed animals faded from her life, migrating to boxes in the attic. But sometimes, when the world outside felt brittle and sharp—when friendships fractured or dreams dissolved—she’d go searching for them, peeling back the tape, running her fingers along the seams she’d once mended herself. In their silence, she remembered love’s patience: how it waits, and how it endures even without return. The animals never spoke, never reached out, but in their quiet presence she found comfort. She realized, years later, that learning to love without expectation was not an emptiness. It was a gentle strength, stitched together by hope and memory.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

My grandmother’s voice was softer now, as if the memories themselves were fragile. I watched her eyes scan the distant tree line beyond our cabin window, searching for something only she could see.

“They always said it was bad luck to swim at dusk,” she continued, fingers tracing the edge of her teacup. “But we were young, and the lake was warm even in September. We dared each other, you know. That’s how it started.”

I listened, drawn into her world of sepia-toned summers, of sunburned shoulders and laughter skimming across the water. But her story shifted, voice lowering.

“That evening, the mist rolled in thick, and we could barely see the dock. Your grandfather dove in after me, thinking I was lost. When he surfaced, he said he’d seen a shadow, something moving just beneath the reeds.”

She paused, eyes distant. “Some things we left in that lake. Some things followed us home.”

I glanced out at the water, suddenly unsure if I wanted to swim there after all.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

Ben’s brow furrowed as he stared at the distant, shimmering surface. Nobody liked talking about the lake after what happened last June. The locals still avoided it, whispering about strange lights beneath the water and ripples that appeared when the air was still.

But curiosity, as always, got the better of us. We crept past the brittle fence, flashlights in hand. The moon was high, making the lake look like a pool of glass. I heard the faintest melody, like someone humming underwater.

Ben shivered. "You hear that?" he whispered.

We stepped closer. The humming grew louder, almost inviting. Suddenly, the water churned, and something slick and pale broke the surface—a hand, gripping the edge of the dock.

We ran. I didn’t look back until we hit the main road. The humming had stopped, replaced by the thrum of my heart. Later, when we told the others, nobody believed us. But Ben and I, we never went back to the swimming lake—some secrets are better left undisturbed.

We reached the dock, its wood soft from years of rain and secrets. Eliza knelt and pressed her palm to the water. For a moment, nothing happened. Then, a faint glow shimmered beneath the lily pads—blue, pulsing, as if the lake itself had a heartbeat.

“Show me,” I whispered.

Eliza closed her eyes. The glow flared, and I saw shapes moving below: lost bicycles, sunken rowboats, a silver ring spinning in the silt. And faces—dozens, gentle and sad, watching from the cool green depths.

The light faded. The frogs resumed their chorus. Eliza opened her eyes and smiled, tired and luminous.

“In the Hudson, the current sweeps things away,” she said. “But in the swimming lake, everything stays.”

“All I wanted was to have her back.” Silence engulfs us for a long time before Mr. Lamont speaks again. His voice catches, barely more than a whisper. “Sometimes, the universe listens, but not in the way you hope.”

I shift in my seat, unsure if I want to hear the rest. Outside the rain hammers the window, relentless and cold. Mr. Lamont’s gaze is fixed on the empty chair across from him, hands trembling around a faded photograph. 

“She was gone for six months. I tried everything—letters, prayers, even that old radio she loved. Then, one night, the air turned strange. The lights flickered. I heard her voice, clear as day, calling my name from the hallway.”

He swallows hard. “But she wasn’t the same. Her eyes… they looked past me, through me. She never spoke again. Just wandered the house, a shadow of herself. I got her back, but I lost her all over again.”

The silence returns, heavier now. I realize I’m gripping my own hands too tightly. Outside, the storm grows louder, as if echoing the ache in the old man’s words.

The grandfather clock ticks, filling the void his words leave behind. I notice the photos on the mantel—one of a girl, laughing, hair wild in the wind. The ache in Mr. Lamont’s posture is palpable, a weight that sags his shoulders.

He finally meets my gaze. “You think you’re prepared for loss, that time will dull it. But grief is a house that rearranges itself every night.”

I want to offer comfort, but the words stick in my throat. Outside, dusk settles, thick and uncertain. Within Mr. Lamont’s silence, I sense a longing that will never quite let go.

Forests, hospitals, even the old mill by the river. Each time I thought I found a sign—a ribbon on a branch, a footprint in the mud—it was just the wind playing tricks."

His hands tremble as he folds and refolds a handkerchief. I try to meet his eyes, but he’s fixed on a point far beyond the window. "They told me to move on. That grief is a journey, not a destination. But what if I never reach the end? What if she’s calling for me from somewhere I can’t follow?"

The clock on the mantle ticks, relentless and loud in the hush. I want to offer reassurance, but all I have is my presence. Outside, a crow lands on the fence and caws. Mr. Lamont flinches, then sighs. "Sometimes I think I hear her, you know. Just laughter in the walls. Maybe that’s all I get."

"All I wanted was to have her back." Silence engulfs us for a long time before Mr. Lamont speaks again. He stares into the fire, the flames painting his face in flickering gold and shadow. "I bargained with the night. Whispered to old gods I never believed in. Left offerings at crossroads and watched the stars for signs."

He laughs, hollow. "Desperation makes poets of us all. But the universe is stingy with miracles. I woke up every morning half-expecting to find her at the kitchen table, grinning over burnt toast. Instead, only dust and sunlight."

I want to ask what he’d do if she really came back. But the question feels cruel. He wipes his eyes with a sleeve and stands, swaying a little. "Some wishes are too big," he says, "and some holes never close. The world keeps spinning, but I’m stuck in yesterday."

The fire snaps, scattering sparks. I sit quietly, unsure if my company is comfort or reminder. Outside, the wind howls, dragging night ever closer.

The attic above is silent, but the air seems charged with longing, and with the promise of one final experiment.

"Subtle car," Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari.

The man glances over, lips quirking into a grin. "Subtlety is for those who want to hide. I prefer to be seen."

Jonah leans on the faded hood of his Civic, arms crossed. "Well, you're definitely hard to miss. What's the occasion?"

The man shrugs, closing the Ferrari’s door with a gentle click. The engine purr is still echoing off the alley walls. "Sometimes you drive to arrive. Sometimes you drive so everyone knows you’ve arrived."

Jonah laughs, shaking his head. "So what brings you to this side of town?"

"Business. And a bit of nostalgia," the man replies, his gaze drifting to the old brick building behind Jonah. "I used to live here, before all this."

Jonah studies the man, noticing the way he avoids looking directly at the building. "Funny how things change."

The man sighs, slipping sunglasses over his eyes. "Some things stay the same."

He turns, tossing Jonah the keys. "Want a taste of the spotlight? Just don’t scratch it."

Jonah’s grin widens. "No promises."

"Subtle car," Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari.

The man glances over, unamused, and adjusts his sharp cufflinks. "It gets me where I need to go," he replies, surveying the cracked pavement and flickering neon around them.

Jonah shoves his hands into his jacket pocket. "Most people use a bus pass for that."

A faint smirk tugs at the man’s lips. "Most people aren’t here for what I’m here for."

He scans the alley, eyes briefly meeting Jonah’s before settling on a battered metal door. Without another word, he strides toward it, shoes clicking in the hush. Jonah follows, curiosity gnawing at him. They slip inside, greeted by the must of old paper and the soft shuffle of cards. A single bulb swings overhead, throwing shadows across a table where a group waits in silence.

"You ready?" Jonah whispers.

The man slides into a chair, Ferrari keys glinting in his fist. "Always."

Outside, the car gleams under the streetlight, ostentatious and out of place—just like its owner.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari.

instance_metrics.response:
"Subtle car," Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari.

The man pauses, a faint smile ghosting across his lips. "You know what they say: go big or go home."

Jonah snorts, kicking at a pebble. "Yeah, but most people just go home."

The man laughs, the sound echoing off the empty parking lot. He reaches into his coat, pulling out a worn photograph. "I suppose I never learned how to be most people."

Jonah takes the photo, squinting at the faded edges. Two boys, arms around each other, grinning at a carnival. "That was us?"

The man nods. "I never forgot. Even after all the noise and the speed, I still remember the quiet days."

Jonah slips the photo into his own pocket. "Maybe you should try subtlety sometime."

The man glances back at the Ferrari and shrugs, a touch of sadness in his eyes. "Maybe I will. But not tonight."

They walk away together, leaving the car—and the past—under the flickering lot lights.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari.

instance_metrics.response:
"Subtle car," Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari.

The man gives a wry smile. "It’s a rental. Had to make an impression."

Jonah laughs, but there’s tension in his voice. "You made one, alright. This place hasn’t seen anything flashier than a secondhand scooter."

The man shrugs, glancing around the half-empty lot. "Sometimes you have to shake things up. Remind people there’s more out there."

Jonah looks away, hands in his pockets. "Maybe. Or maybe you just like the noise."

The man’s eyes soften. "Maybe I do. But not all noise is bad. Sometimes it brings people together."

Jonah studies him, uncertain. "So, why’d you come back? After all these years?"

The man sighs, running a hand through his slick hair. "Looking for something I left behind. Maybe someone."

Jonah’s expression shifts. "Well, you found me."

For a moment, the Ferrari’s engine ticks quietly in the darkness, and the two men just stand there—together, but not quite home.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari.

instance_metrics.response:
"Subtle car," Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari.

The man, unfazed, flicks a speck of imagined dust from his lapel. "You can’t hide if you never intend to disappear."

Jonah grins, watching the way the streetlights glint off the car’s crimson curves. "Is that the secret, then?"

The man’s eyes meet Jonah’s, sharp and amused. "There are no secrets, only stories we tell ourselves."

He tosses Jonah a small velvet pouch. It lands with a weighty thud in Jonah’s palm. Inside: a single silver key and a folded scrap of paper. Jonah’s pulse quickens. He unfolds the note: ‘Tonight, 11:45. Rooftop. Trust yourself.’

When Jonah looks up, the man is already halfway down the block, vanishing into the shadows. The Ferrari’s engine remains silent, keys now in Jonah’s hand. Heart pounding, Jonah slips behind the wheel, the unfamiliar luxury wrapping around him like a dare.

He glances at the clock—11:40. Whatever story this was, it was about to begin, and for once, Jonah was in the driver’s seat.

The two journalists sat in the cramped car, listening to the rain drum on the windshield. The recorder was between them, its red light blinking in anticipation. Urueta’s house, a faded blue bungalow with a creaking porch, loomed just ahead. 

“He’ll talk,” Maria whispered, squeezing the notebook in her lap. “He always folds under pressure. Remember last year at the docks?”

Jonas remembered. Urueta had ranted for forty minutes about the price of shrimp, then accidentally revealed the entire smuggling operation. 

A light flickered in the window. Jonas straightened his tie. “If he slams the door, we try the back.”

Maria smirked. “We bring him coffee and cigarettes. If that fails, we tell him his rival’s already talking.”

They stepped out, boots splashing in the puddles, and approached the porch. Before Jonas could knock, Urueta swung open the door. 

“You again,” he grumbled, but there was a glint in his eye. “Come in, but no more questions about the shrimp.”

Maria grinned. “We came for the stories only you can tell.”

“He doesn’t like us.”

Carmen adjusted her glasses, peering around the corner of the crowded café. Urueta sat alone, swirling sugar into his espresso, his brow furrowed.

“He’s not going to say yes if we just walk up,” I whispered.

Carmen shrugged. “He likes an audience. Let’s give him one.” She marched forward, her confidence a shield. I trailed, clutching the recorder. 

“Señor Urueta, might we join you?” Carmen asked, bright and unyielding.

He eyed us, lips pressed thin. “If you’re here about the council, I have nothing to say.”

“We’re here for the stories you haven’t told yet,” Carmen replied, sliding into the booth. “Not the ones everyone’s heard.”

Urueta’s eyes flickered. He hesitated, then nodded. “You want the truth, not gossip?”

I pressed record. Carmen leaned in. “We want to listen.”

Outside, the city moved on unaware, but inside that dim café, the old man began to talk. His words tumbled out, one secret at a time, and we were ready to catch them all.

The newsroom buzzed around Gloria and Mateo as they studied the cracked photograph pinned to their corkboard. Urueta, the elusive councilman, was known for his sharp tongue and evasive answers, but his penchant for lengthy monologues was legendary.

“He’s just wary. Last time, you asked about the missing funds,” Mateo said, clicking his pen. “Maybe we go in softer this time.”

Gloria smirked. “You mean, charm him with pastries?”

“Something like that. He’s got a sweet tooth.”

The next afternoon, armed with a box of sugared empanadas, they found Urueta pacing outside the community hall. He glanced at the box suspiciously, then at the two reporters. “Bribery?”

“Hospitality,” Gloria replied, extending an empanada.

He hesitated, then took it. “Alright. You get twenty minutes. No trick questions.”

As he spoke, the minutes stretched. Urueta’s words poured out, stories tangled with confessions. Gloria scribbled furiously, knowing she’d finally unlocked the interview that would change everything.

Inside, Urueta began to speak. His words were slow at first, but soon his voice filled the room, stories tumbling out, painting a world Ana and Javier had only guessed at. By the time he finished, they knew they’d heard something no one else ever had.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

We stood on the old dock, the planks creaking beneath our feet. Mist curled off the surface, hiding the far shore. Caleb’s grin was sly. “I saw something last night. Something moving.”

I rolled my eyes. “You’re always seeing things.”

“No, really. It was huge. Bigger than a person.”

The water lapped quietly. Somewhere, a loon called. I shivered, but not from the cold.

“Maybe it was a beaver.”

Caleb shook his head. “No tail slap. This was different.”

We peered into the gray water. A ripple fanned out, as if something had just dived beneath. I took a step back. Caleb didn’t move.

“You’re not going in, are you?” I whispered.

He smiled, kicked off his sneakers, and leaped. The splash echoed. I waited, breath held.

Seconds passed. Then, a hand broke the surface, holding something: a smooth, ancient stone, etched with symbols.

Caleb’s eyes were wide with wonder. “Told you. There’s something in here.”

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

I stared at Julia, her hair still wet from the dive. “You’re sure it was the same ring?”

She nodded, holding out her palm. The gold band glinted, caked in mud. We both looked back at the dark water, its surface unbroken, innocent.

“My grandfather lost it sixty years ago,” she said, voice trembling. “He said it slipped off in the river. But—this isn’t the Hudson.”

A breeze shivered through the trees. I felt a chill, something not from the air. I crouched down, peering at the ring. Strange markings lined the inside, old and unfamiliar.

“Maybe the lakes are connected,” I whispered, thinking of the stories, of tunnels and currents beneath the town.

Julia slipped the ring onto her finger. For a moment, the world seemed to hush. The lake, the wind, even the birds paused.

Then, from somewhere deep below, a sound: a faint, echoing chime. We held our breath, listening. Something old had awakened.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

I watched as the old man pointed, his finger trembling toward the glimmering water. The sun was setting, painting the surface gold. He shuffled closer, lowering his voice like a secret.

“They say something lives down there. Not a fish, not a turtle. Something older.”

I laughed, but my skin prickled. “You mean like a monster?”

He shrugged, smiling without humor. “My brother disappeared one summer afternoon. Just dove in and never came up. We searched for days. Never found him.”

The water lapped at the shore, gentle and inviting. I thought of all the kids who swam here, splashing, shouting, never imagining what lay beneath.

“Do you ever swim here?” I asked.

He shook his head, eyes distant. “Not anymore.”

As the last light faded, I stared at the lake, wondering if it really was safer than the Hudson—or if every body of water keeps its own secrets.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

The distinction was important. The Hudson, with its churning, brackish waves, was no place for a delicate operation. The swimming lake, quiet and secluded, offered the privacy we needed.

We crept along the shore at dusk, shovels in hand. The box was heavier than I remembered. Owen glanced at me, nervous in the fading light.

“You think anyone saw us?” he whispered.

I shook my head. “No one comes here after dark.”

We dug in silence, the air thick with anticipation. When the hole was deep enough, we lowered the box in, covering it with dark, lake-wet earth. The water lapped gently, as if approving the secret.

Before we left, Owen tossed a stone into the lake, marking the spot. We promised each other we’d never speak of it again.

But the lake remembers, and every summer, when the water warms and children laugh on the shore, I wonder if our secret stirs beneath the mud, waiting to be uncovered.

The question lingered in the humid air, mingling with the chorus of cicadas. Ellie hesitated on the edge of the dock, her toes curled over the splintered wood.

“But why would you hide it here?” she asked, squinting through the dusk at Sam, who was already wading waist-deep into the lake. His silhouette shimmered, distorted by ripples and memory.

“Because nobody looks for lost things in places meant for joy,” Sam replied, his voice echoing across the water. He ducked beneath the surface, and Ellie’s heart pounded as the lake swallowed him whole.

Seconds ticked by—too many. Just as she was about to shout, Sam surfaced, gasping, clutching a tarnished locket in his fist. He grinned, breathless.

“See? Not everything lost is gone forever,” he said, handing it to her. The locket was cold and slimy, but its engraving was unmistakable.

Ellie traced the initials, her eyes stinging. The lake, once ordinary, now shimmered with the possibility of secrets returned.

I waited outside the café, tapping my fingers on the wooden table. The sun was setting, painting the glass windows orange. My editor’s words echoed in my mind. Maybe I was too insistent; maybe I should have let Urueta come to me. But stories like his didn’t wait for patience.

When he finally slid into the seat across from me, he looked exhausted, but there was a spark in his eyes. “You want the truth or the legend?” he asked, voice rough from too many cigarettes.

“Both,” I said, flipping open my recorder.

He grinned—a reluctant concession. “Fine. But you won’t like the truth.”

As we talked, Urueta’s tension faded. He leaned in, gesturing with his hands, words tumbling out in bursts. He told me about the night the river flooded, the decision that changed everything, and the secret he’d carried for twenty years.

By the time he finished, the café was empty, and I had the story I never expected to hear.

I paced in the humid corridor of the Palacio, shoes squeaking against the marble. My badge itched at my collarbone. Urueta’s secretary, a thin man with a lopsided tie, appeared with a clipboard. “He will see you now. But only for seven minutes.”

The office was a jungle—vines curling from pots, books piled like fortresses, a parrot watching from its perch. Urueta lounged behind his desk, fingers drumming a rhythm only he understood. He didn’t look up. “You’re the persistent one?”

“Yes, sir.”

He sighed theatrically. “Fine. I’ll give you a story. But not the one you want.”

I sat, pen poised, as he launched into a tale about his childhood in Veracruz, chasing storms and learning to mend boats. He described the day he found a message in a bottle—two words in smeared ink: ‘Trust her.’

The clock ticked. Seven minutes passed. He stood, smiling slyly. “You get one question. Make it count.”

I hesitated, then asked, “Did you ever trust her?”

Urueta’s eyes softened, just for a moment. “Every day.”

August hesitated, fingers fidgeting with the smooth marbles in his palm. The circle of friends around him waited, their faces glowing in the lantern’s flicker. “Truth or dare?” Julian pressed, his eyes dancing with mischief. August looked down, then up, his voice barely above a whisper. “Truth.”

A collective groan rose, but Julian grinned, undeterred. “Okay, August. If you could be anyone else for a day, who would you be?”

August thought about it, the weight of all the ways he felt different pressing in. The group waited, expecting a joke, a celebrity, something light. But August surprised them all. “I’d be myself,” he said quietly, “but without worrying what everyone thinks of me.”

The silence that followed was heavier than the air before a summer storm. Then, one by one, his friends nodded, understanding more than words could ever say. In that circle, August found something he hadn’t expected: acceptance, in the simplest truth he could share.

August laughed nervously, but the group’s anticipation spurred him on. “Okay, so…I once dreamed our school was floating in space, tethered to the moon by a giant licorice rope. Everyone walked upside down in zero gravity, and the teachers handed out homework made of marshmallows. At lunch, we ate pizza that tasted like starlight, and Principal Harris turned into a talking owl.”

The friends burst out laughing, the tension melting away. Julian clapped August on the back. “See? That’s the kind of stuff we want to hear!”

As the night deepened, August felt the warmth of belonging, his weirdness no longer something to hide, but something to be celebrated.

“Urueta is going to give you the interview you need sooner or later.”

“He doesn’t like us.”

“He got a little tense, but Urueta loves talking.”

The two journalists leaned against the chipped marble banister, watching Urueta pace the colonnade. The afternoon sun slanted through the arches, catching the nervous flick of his fingers as he dialed and re-dialed a number on his phone. It was rumored he’d blown the whistle on his own department, but no one knew what for. 

“I heard he keeps a dossier on everyone who ever crossed him,” whispered Elena, glancing at her recorder. “Maybe that’s why he’s stalling.”

Marek shrugged. “Or he’s just waiting for the right audience.”

As if on cue, Urueta turned. His expression was unreadable, but his stride was decisive. He stopped before them, eyes darting over their notepads. For a moment, the only sound was the distant hum of traffic and the clack of a pigeon’s claws on stone.

“Let’s walk,” he said. “I need to get out of here.”

They hurried after him, hearts pounding, knowing the real story was about to begin.

My pulse quickened. I reached for the switch, realizing this was the moment we’d been waiting for—the story behind the story, the one he’d only share when he thought nobody else was listening.

All I wanted was to have her back.” Silence engulfs us for a long time before Mr. Lamont speaks again. His voice is rough, as if each word is being dragged from somewhere deep and painful. “But we don’t always get what we want, do we?”

I watch him, unsure whether he’s expecting an answer or simply venting to the empty, dust-choked air of the study. The fire in the grate has burned low, casting wild shadows on his face. I clutch the letter in my hand—the one addressed in her neat, looping script, postmarked a week before the accident. I haven’t dared to open it.

Mr. Lamont stands, moving slowly to the window. “You’re her friend. You knew her, before.” His eyes search mine, pleading for something I can’t give. “Tell me. If there’s a way…?”

I shake my head, words failing me. Outside, rain traces rivers down the glass. I wonder if the letter holds the answers he wants, or if it will only deepen the ache we share in this silent room.

His father was alive beside her. This simple fact, which should have been comforting, instead made the air in the small room feel taut and strange. Mara sat on the edge of the bed, hands clasped tightly, her gaze flickering between the two men. His father, who had been presumed lost at sea for nearly a year, appeared unchanged except for the wildness in his eyes—a spark of something old and fierce. In contrast, her husband looked aged, the weight of hope and grief having settled into the lines of his face.

Neither man spoke. The only sound was the ticking of the clock above the mantle, each second punctuating the impossible reunion. Mara wondered if either of them would break the silence, or if the gulf built by months of absence and whispered prayers would remain. When the father's hand finally reached out, trembling, Mara felt her breath catch. The world seemed to tilt, full of possibility and dread, as the past and present collided in the hush of their tiny home.

His father was alive beside her. That’s what she whispered, over and over, as if saying it aloud would make it real. The candlelight flickered across the man’s face, casting shadows that danced and retreated. All these years, all the birthdays missed and the empty chair at dinner—gone in a single evening’s revelation. But something in the way he sat, too upright, too quiet, unsettled her. It wasn’t just the miracle of his return; it was the question of what had changed in the years he’d been gone. She eyed the small scar beneath his right ear—a scar he hadn’t had before—and wondered what else the shadows concealed.

Outside, the wind rattled the windowpane, as if urging her to ask the questions she feared. Instead, she poured him tea with trembling hands and tried to remember the man he’d been, even as she struggled to accept the man he’d become. In the hush between them, the past and present coiled tightly together, waiting for the right moment to unravel.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty gnawed at her soul. He told me this tale over bitter ale in a windswept inn on the Isle of Man. His eyes, rimmed with salt, wandered as if searching for her shadow among the flickering candlelight. 

"She returned changed," he said. "Her laughter was too bright, her gaze too distant. She would sit on the cliffs, staring at the sea, humming songs no one on this earth had heard before." The faeries had gifted her silks that shimmered like sunrise and a voice that could charm the wind, but they had taken her memory of home. 

One morning, she walked into the tide, her pockets filled with pebbles and petals from the faerie glen. The islanders whispered of curses and bargains, but the Manx man only wept for the daughter whose heart could not bear the ache of mortal life after tasting impossible beauty. 

He never forgave the faeries, nor himself, and I have never forgotten the sorrow in his tale.
